characters: HUNDREDS OF MATHEMATICAL PAPERS ARE SCATTERED ALL OVER HE
ON HUGH, ALAN, JOAN, AND HELEN
ON HUGH, ALAN, JOHN, AND PETER

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: Good. This is going to go very quickly now. If you are not listening carefully, you will miss things. Important things. You’re writing some of this down? That’s good. INSIDE ALAN’S HOUSE: There's been a break-in, and the hou is a mess - someone has given it a pretty thorough once-o

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: I will not pause, I will not repeat myself, and you will not interrupt me. If you ask me a question, I will ignore it. You think that because you’re sitting where you are, and I am sitting where I am, that you are in control of what is about to happen. You’re mistaken. I am in control, because I know things that you do not know. PAPERS inked black with mathematical symbols litter the floor. The test tubes and beakers of Turing's chemical wo are shattered in the study, CYANIDE and POTASSIUM NITRATE DRIPPING ACROSS THE UGLY CARPET.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: What I will need from you now is a commitment. You will listen closely, and you will not judge me. And, in the corner: A MACHINE. It’s the size of a dresser tall, sprouting VACUUM TUBES and WIRES. It looks anachronistic here, too futuristic for its time. The CONSTABLES LOOK AT THE MACHINE, CONFUSED: What is tha thing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When I am finished — when I have told you that I am finished — you are free to think whatever you like. But until then, you will trust that while this story will be hard for you to understand, everything I am saying I am saying for a reason. A CONSTABLE PHONES IN the robbery to police headquarters

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: — At headquarters, a RADIO GIRL RECEIVES the information passes it to an assistant for delivery to the detectives duty — INT. MI-6 - RADIO OPERATORS’ ROOM/HALLWAYS - DAY — While in London, a RADIO OPERATOR in a dark room far be Victoria Street INTERCEPTS THE MESSAGE —

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: If you cannot commit to this, then please leave the room. That’s right, you’re the one who’s free to go. But if you choose to stay, if you choose to listen, remember this: If things happen that you do not like, you chose to be here. — The MESSAGE is HANDED OFF and WHISKED through the dim hallways —

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: — Until it’s finally deposited on the desk of STEWART MENZIES, the Director of MI-6. British Secret Intelligenc Services.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: What happens from this moment forward is not my responsibility: It’s yours. Menzies picks up the message: “Alan Turing has been robbe

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: This will go quite fast now. (laughs) And that is the last time I will repeat myself. Pay attention.  EXT. ALAN TURNING’S HOUSE - MORNING DETECTIVE ROBERT NOCK, 40s, athletic, more interested in football than being a detective, hustles past a few doubl parked police cars and up the steps and into: INT. ALAN TURNING’S HOUSE - CONTINUOUS Detective Nock enters to find the same messy crime scene just saw. He’s addressed by SERGEANT STAEHL.

dialogues.speaker: SGT. STAEHL
dialogues.text: Bit late, don’t you think?

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE NOCK
dialogues.text: The baby. Up all night, hollering and crying. June says it’s collick. (cre: the mess) What’s all this, then?

dialogues.speaker: SGT. STAEHL
dialogues.text: Turing, Alan. Professor at King’s. Seems there’s been a robbery.

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE NOCK
dialogues.text: What of?

dialogues.speaker: SGT. STAEHL
dialogues.text: That’s just it. Nothing’s missing, really.

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE NOCK
dialogues.text: No, what’s he a professor of?

dialogues.speaker: SGT. STAEHL
dialogues.text: (consulting notes) Maths. Or, as he put it, “ordinal logic, with a dose of number theory.” ON NOCK: What on earth does that mean? Staehl shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE NOCK
dialogues.text: What’s he doing in Manchester? Sergeant Staehl shows Nock the MACHINE in the corner. ON NOCK: What the hell is that?

dialogues.speaker: SGT. STAEHL
dialogues.text: Something with machines. Project at the NPL, I checked, but he won’t say what it’s on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He’s a bit squirrely then, our Professor Turing?

dialogues.speaker: SGT. STAEHL
dialogues.text: That’s putting it mildly. Sergeant Staehl motions to the next room, and he follows in... ++. Where they find ALAN TURING, 38. He’s the smartest ma the room, and he knows it. But he doesn’t really care if do. Turing is VERY CAREFULLY sweeping up a pile of WHITE POWD He’s doing it with a PAINTBRUSH, his mouth covered in a scarf. He’s totally oblivious to the detectives as they enter.

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE NOCK
dialogues.text: Professor Turing? (beat) Professor Turing? My name is Detective Nock. Manchester Police. Sergeant Staehl here tells me you've had a robbery last night. (still nothing) Professor Turing? Detective Nock steps closer, peering over Turing’s should at the white powder. DETECTIVE NOCK (CONT’D) Professor —

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: — I would step back, if I were you.

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE NOCK
dialogues.text: Pardon me?

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: Step back, and don’t breathe so much.

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE NOCK
dialogues.text: Breathe?

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: You're breathing heavily and you’re going to inhale this junk and you're going to leave your collicky son without a father.  Detective Nock stops, and steps back. What in the world? ALAN TURING (CONT’D) Sound carries in this house.

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE NOCK
dialogues.text: What is all that?

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: Cyanide. Undiluted. Wouldn’t take more than a thimbleful to kill you. Turing finishes sweeping the cyanide into a jar, before safely CAPPING IT. Turing stands, removes his scarf, and for the first time takes a look at Detective Nock. Sizes him up. ALAN TURING (CONT’D) Oh. Disappointing. Detective Knock and Sergeant Staehl exchange a look.

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE NOCK
dialogues.text: Pardon?

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: I'd hoped for a bit more.

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE NOCK
dialogues.text: Sergeant Staehl, is it just me, or do you get the sense that we’re being insulted?

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: (to Nock) You lied to your friend here about your son, which is just unseemly. Collick didn’t keep you up all night. Drink did. You’ve bags under your eyes the size of strawberries. Your topcoat reeks of whiskey. You're short of breath after walking 30 paces. And I believe Manchester United had a match yesterday, yes? I could hear the shouting from Simpson’s on my way home.

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE NOCK
dialogues.text: (caught) ++. We won by four. Would’ve been unseemly not to celebrate. Sergeant Staehl SIGHS, embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You had a break in last night. Your neighbor, a Mr. Springborn, called to report the noise. Only you say there’s nothing missing. Odd. So how about it — You tell us what happened, and we find the chap who did this.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: Gentlemen, I don’t think you could figure out who broke into my house if he walked up and spat in your face. What I could really use at the moment is not a bobby but a good cleaning lady. So unless one of you has an apron in your car, I'd suggest that you file your reports and leave me alone. Staehl is about to say something — and probably something aggressive, by the look of his face — but Nock stops him.

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE NOCK
dialogues.text: ++. As you say, Professor Turing. Best of luck with your cyanide. EXT. ALAN TURNING’S HOUSE - MOMENTS LATER Detective Nock and Sergeant Staehl walk away from Turing’ house.

dialogues.speaker: SGT. STAEHL
dialogues.text: I'll give you a bob if you can name me a more insufferable sod.

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE NOCK
dialogues.text: Curious, isn’t he?

dialogues.speaker: SGT. STAEHL
dialogues.text: Oh, you've a soft spot for the bastard ‘cause he called you on your drink? Which, while we’re on the subject —

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE NOCK
dialogues.text: — Seemed a bit forced though, didn’t it?

dialogues.speaker: SGT. STAEHL
dialogues.text: Don’t know what you mean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you didn’t want a pair of bobbies digging around in your personal affairs, well, that would have been a stellar way to see that they don’t. Tell me you don’t think this is suspicious.

dialogues.speaker: SGT. STAEHL
dialogues.text: I don’t think this is suspicious.

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE NOCK
dialogues.text: A mysterious professor who won’t admit he’s had something stolen from his flat?

dialogues.speaker: SGT. STAEHL
dialogues.text: What’re you suggesting?

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE NOCK
dialogues.text: I’m suggesting that Alan Turing is hiding something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alan Turing — 11 years younger — HURRIES through Euston Station on the day that Britain declares war on Germany. The station is preparing for war: PAPERBOYS SCREAM the headlines: “800,000 CHILDREN EVACUAT “GERMAN BOMBS COMING!” “FOOD SUPPLIES RATIONED!” MILITARY PERSONNEL herd PACKS OF CHILDREN like cattle ont rumbling trains. The children, born with stiff upper lips, hold back their tears. A FATHER shakes the hand of his 8-YEAR-OLD SON goodbye, almost business-like. Neither knows if they’ll e see one another again. Alan moves through this determinedly, methodically, and unemotionally — it’s like he doesn’t even notice anyone i there.

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. TRAIN
dialogues.text: Alan Turing walks down the aisle of a train bound for Bletchley Park — his is the only adult face amidst the se children. He watches a SMALL BOY pour over a PUZZLE BOOK. OLDER KI loud and rowdy, TAUNT the Small Boy, who doesn’t look up, he’s so focused on his puzzles. Alan watches. Maybe he smiles. Maybe he understands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alan walks through the small village of Bletchley. He pas a sign that reads “BLETCHLEY RADIO MANUFACTURING” as he h to

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alan arrives at the imposing front gates of Bletchley Par An enormous Victorian mansion lies in the center of the grounds, surrounded by empty gardens and tall iron fences As Alan approaches, two NAVAL OFFICERS with MACHINE GUNS out from behind the BARRICADES. Whatever this place is, it’s housing something very secre inside. INT. BLETCHLEY PARK - COMMANDER DENNISTON’S OFFICE - LATE A few minutes later, Alan sits alone in a cluttered offic He stares ahead blankly at the empty chair behind the des Waits.

dialogues.speaker: COMMANDER DENNISTON, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: — What are you doing here? Alan turns with a start.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: The girl told me to wait —

dialogues.speaker: COMMANDER DENNISTON
dialogues.text: In my office? She tell you to help yourself to a cup of tea while you were here?

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: No. She didn’t.

dialogues.speaker: COMMANDER DENNISTON
dialogues.text: She didn’t tell you what a joke is then either, I gather.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: Was she supposed to?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For Christ’s sake — who are you?

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: Alan Turing.

dialogues.speaker: COMMANDER DENNISTON
dialogues.text: (looking at papers on his desk) Turing... Let me see... Oh, Turing. The mathematician.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: Correct.

dialogues.speaker: COMMANDER DENNISTON
dialogues.text: How ever could I have guessed?

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: You didn’t. It was written on your paper.

dialogues.speaker: COMMANDER DENNISTON
dialogues.text: ++. King’s College, Cambridge. Says here you were a bit of a prodigy in the maths department.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: I’m not sure I can evaluate that, Mr... ?

dialogues.speaker: COMMANDER DENNISTON
dialogues.text: How old are you, Mr. Turing?

dialogues.speaker: COMMANDER DENNISTON
dialogues.text: How old were you when you became a fellow at Cambridge?

dialogues.speaker: COMMANDER DENNISTON
dialogues.text: And how old were you when you published this paper here, that has a title I can barely understand, which apparently got you this fellowship?

dialogues.speaker: COMMANDER DENNISTON
dialogues.text: And you don’t think that qualifies you as a certified prodigy?

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: Rather depends on how old my peers were when they did comparable work, doesn’t it?

dialogues.speaker: COMMANDER DENNISTON
dialogues.text: And how old were they?

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: Newton discovered the binomial theorem at 22. Einstein published four papers that changed the world at 26. As far as I can tell I’ve barely made par.

dialogues.speaker: COMMANDER DENNISTON
dialogues.text: You're serious, aren’t you?

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: Would you prefer I make a joke?

dialogues.speaker: COMMANDER DENNISTON
dialogues.text: Not sure you know what those are.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: It hardly seems fair that that would be a requirement for employment here, Mr...?

dialogues.speaker: COMMANDER DENNISTON
dialogues.text: Commander Denniston, of the Royal Navy. All right, Mr. Turing, I’1l bite. Why do you want to work for His Majesty’s government?

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: Oh, I don’t, really.

dialogues.speaker: COMMANDER DENNISTON
dialogues.text: (suspicious) Are you a bleeding pacifist, Turing?

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: I’m agnostic about violence.

dialogues.speaker: COMMANDER DENNISTON
dialogues.text: But you realize that 600 miles from London there’s this nasty chap named Hitler who’s looking to engulf Europe in tyranny?  11.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: Politics is not my area of expertise.

dialogues.speaker: COMMANDER DENNISTON
dialogues.text: I believe you’ve just set a record for the shortest job interview in British military history.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: Mother says that I can be off- putting sometimes. On account of being the best mathematician in the world.

dialogues.speaker: COMMANDER DENNISTON
dialogues.text: You're the best mathematician in the world?

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: Oh. Yes.

dialogues.speaker: COMMANDER DENNISTON
dialogues.text: ++. Do you know how many people I've rejected for this program?

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: COMMANDER DENNISTON
dialogues.text: That’s right. Because we’re a top secret program. But I’1ll tell you, just because we’re friends, that last week I rejected one of our great nation’s top linguists, knows German better than Bertolt Brecht.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: I don’t speak German.

dialogues.speaker: COMMANDER DENNISTON
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: I don’t. Speak German.

dialogues.speaker: COMMANDER DENNISTON
dialogues.text: How the bloody hell are you supposed to decrypt German communications if you don’t, oh, I don’t know, speak German?

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: I’m quite excellent at crossword puzzles.  And for a 12.

dialogues.speaker: COMMANDER DENNISTON
dialogues.text: (calling off)

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: The German codes are a puzzle. A game. Just like any other game.

dialogues.speaker: COMMANDER DENNISTON
dialogues.text: MARGARET! Where are you?!

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: I'm very good at games. Puzzles. And I think this is the hardest puzzle in the world.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: (beat) For the love of. obviously. This is a joke,

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: I’m afraid I can’t make jokes, Commander Denniston. split second, Denniston actually smiles.

dialogues.speaker: COMMANDER DENNISTON
dialogues.text: Have a pleasant trip back to Cambridge, Professor.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: Enigma. At the mention of this word Denniston looks suddenly seri

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY, ("MARGARET")
dialogues.text: (popping head in) You called for me? He WAVES HER AWAY, entirely focused on what Alan just sai

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: (after she leaves) ++. That’s what you’re doing here. The top secret program at Bletchley. You’re trying to break the German Enigma machine.

dialogues.speaker: COMMANDER DENNISTON
dialogues.text: What makes you think that?

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: It’s the greatest encryption device in history, and the Germans use it for all major communications. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: If the Allies broke Enigma — well, this would turn into a very short war indeed. Of course you’re working on it. But you also haven't got anywhere. If you had, you wouldn’t be hiring cryptographers out of University. You need me a lot more than I need you. I'd just as easily go work for the Germans, frankly, but they simply don’t have anything this good to work on. Our mathematicians aren’t as impressive as theirs. With one significant exception. I like solving problems, Commander. And Enigma is the most difficult problem in the world.

dialogues.speaker: COMMANDER DENNISTON
dialogues.text: Enigma isn’t difficult. It’s impossible. The Americans. The French. The Russians. The Germans. Everyone thinks Enigma is unbreakable.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: Goody! Let me try and we'll know for sure. The men stare at each other. Neither blinks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGLE ON: A machine. It looks like a typewriter that got on the set of Blade Runner. Wires running all over it. Ex gears sticking out of the sides. Blinking lights that rev German characters. Half electrical, half mechanical.

dialogues.speaker: COMMANDER DENNISTON, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Welcome to Enigma. SLOWLY REVEAL: COMMANDER DENNISTON, 50s, is showing the ENIGMA MACHINE to the NEW RECRUITS. They are: HUGH ALEXANDER, 30s, loves women and chess in equal measu JOHN CAIRNCROSS, 30s, Scottish, not the prodigy his compatriots are and knows it. PETER HILTON, 20s, a precocious undergrad from Oxford. KEITH FURMAN and CHARLES RICHARDS, 40s, both stodgy linguists.  14. Stewart Menzies — head of MI-6, who we briefly glimpsed i the opening — stands in the corner, silent and observing. Charming and inscrutable, he didn’t become the head of British Secret Intelligence Services by accident.

dialogues.speaker: COMMANDER DENNISTON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The German navy encodes every message they send using the Enigma machine. The details of every surprise attack, of every secret convoy, of every U-Boat in the bloody Atlantic go into that thing, and out comes... Gibberish. FINALLY REVEAL: ... Alan stands with them, staring at the machine like it’s the Sistine Chapel. He reaches out and touches it lovingly.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: It’s beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: COMMANDER DENNISTON
dialogues.text: It’s the crooked hand of death itself. Denniston shows Alan sheets of Enigma messages: PAGE AFTE PAGE OF RANDOM LETTERS.

dialogues.speaker: COMMANDER DENNISTON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Our WRENs intercept thousands of radio messages a day. But to the lovely young ladies of the Women’s Royal Navy, they’re nonsense. It’s only when you feed them back into Enigma that they make sense.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN CAIRNCROSS
dialogues.text: But we have an Enigma machine.

dialogues.speaker: COMMANDER DENNISTON
dialogues.text: Yes. Polish intelligence smuggled this out of Berlin.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN CAIRNCROSS
dialogues.text: So what’s the problem? Just put the intercepted messages back in to Enigma and —

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: — It’s not that simple, is it? Just having an Enigma machine doesn’t help you decode the messages.  15.

dialogues.speaker: COMMANDER DENNISTON
dialogues.text: Very good, Mr. Turing. To decode a message, you need to know the machine’s settings. The Germans switch settings every day, promptly at midnight. We usually intercept our first message around 6am. Which gives you exactly 18 hours every day to crack the code before it changes, and you start again. Alan looks at the machine carefully.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: Five rotors. Six plugboard cables. That's...

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES RICHARDS
dialogues.text: Five —

dialogues.speaker: JOHN CAIRNCROSS
dialogues.text: — thousand million —

dialogues.speaker: PETER HILTON
dialogues.text: — No no it’s — I've got it —

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES RICHARDS
dialogues.text: — Million, million —

dialogues.speaker: KEITH FURMAN
dialogues.text: -— In the millions, obviously —

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES RICHARDS
dialogues.text: — Obviously —

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: — Over one hundred and fifty million million million possible settings. All eyes turn to Turing: Wow.

dialogues.speaker: COMMANDER DENNISTON
dialogues.text: ++. Very good.

dialogues.speaker: HUGH ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: One hundred fifty nine, if you'd rather be exact about it. Everyone looks at Hugh now. HUGH ALEXANDER (CONT’D) One five nine with eighteen zeroes behind it. Possibilities. Every single day. Jesus Christ. Who is this guy?  16.

dialogues.speaker: COMMANDER DENNISTON
dialogues.text: Gentlemen, meet Hugh Alexander. I’ve personally selected him to run this unit.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN CAIRNCROSS
dialogues.text: Didn’t you...?

dialogues.speaker: COMMANDER DENNISTON
dialogues.text: Mr. Alexander won Britain's national chess championship.

dialogues.speaker: HUGH ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: Twice.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN CAIRNCROSS
dialogues.text: (extending a hand to Hugh) John Cairncross.

dialogues.speaker: COMMANDER DENNISTON
dialogues.text: (to Alan) You’re not the only one who’s good at games around here.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: Are we all to work together then? I prefer to have my own office.

dialogues.speaker: COMMANDER DENNISTON
dialogues.text: You're a team, and you’ll work as one.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: I don’t have time to explain myself as I go along, and I’m afraid these men will only slow me down.

dialogues.speaker: STEWART MENZIES
dialogues.text: (piping up from the corner) -— If you can’t play together, then I’m afraid we can’t let you play at all. They all stare at him.

dialogues.speaker: COMMANDER DENNISTON
dialogues.text: This is Stuart Menzies. MI-6. The team ACKNOWLEDGES Menzies.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES RICHARDS
dialogues.text: There are only five divisions of military intelligence. There is no “MI-6."”  17.

dialogues.speaker: STEWART MENZIES
dialogues.text: Exactly. That’s the spirit. (to Alan) Mr. Turing. Do you know how many British servicemen have died because of Enigma?

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: I don’t.

dialogues.speaker: STEWART MENZIES
dialogues.text: Three. They all stare at Menzies: That doesn’t sound like very m

dialogues.speaker: STEWART MENZIES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ».. While we've been having this conversation. (checks his watch) Oh look. There’s another. Rather hope he didn’t have a family. This war that Commander Denniston’s been going on about? We’re not winning it. Break the code and at least we might have a chance. (to Denniston) Shall we leave the children alone with their new toy? Menzies and Commander Denniston LEAVE. The team stands there. With Enigma.

dialogues.speaker: HUGH ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: Alright boys. Let’s play.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TEENAGE BOYS play cricket in the green front gardens of a boys boarding school. Behind them looms the school’s stat central manor house.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: The problem began, of course, with the carrots.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: YOUNG ALAN TURING, 15, sits alone in the dining hall. Oth BOYS joke and laugh and tell animated stories at nearby tables, but Alan sits alone, staring intently at his food  18. ON ALAN’S PLATE: Boiled steak. Potatoes. Peas. And carrot

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: Carrots are orange. Peas are green. They mustn’t touch. Alan carefully tries to separate the carrots from the pea It’s like he’s performing brain surgery. BEHIND ALAN, a group of BIGGER BOYS approach quietly. One them holds a TRAY OF BOILED VEGETABLES — — The Boys try to MUFFLE THEIR GIGGLES so Alan can’t hear them approach — — The Boys DUMP THE TRAY OF VEGETABLES ALL OVER ALAN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alan SCREAMS. The Boys LAUGH as Alan SCREAMS and SHAKES and tries to ge the peas and carrots and everything else off of him. He’s hell. Alan FALLS DOWN. Still shaking, still screaming.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG ALAN
dialogues.text: Carrots are orange! Carrots are orange! Carrots are orange!

dialogues.speaker: BOY
dialogues.text: What a bloody weirdo! Alan CURLS UP INTO A BALL as he shivers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ++. Alan is now inside a coffin. He’s KICKING AT THE WOODEN BOARDS ABOVE and SCREAMING TO RELEASED. It’s not helping. From above, we hear the familiar LAUGHTER OF THE SCHOOLBO REVEAL: The “coffin” is make-shift; the Boys have constru it out of the broken floorboards of a half-finished class room. Alan is buried underground, and they’re nailing him

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: Do you know why people like violence? Because it feels good. The THUMP THUMP of nails entering the boards.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: Humans find violence deeply satisfying. But remove the satisfaction, and the act becomes... Hollow. FROM INSIDE THE COFFIN: Alan goes silent. The Boys pound away, but the silence unnerves them.

dialogues.speaker: BOY
dialogues.text: Alan? Alan?

dialogues.speaker: BOY
dialogues.text: C’mon don’t be such a kike about it...

dialogues.speaker: BOY
dialogues.text: Leave him to bloody rot. The Boys LEAVE. There’s still only SILENCE from inside Alan’s coffin. Alan breathes slowly. Quietly. Controls his shivering to barely a tremor. He waits.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: I didn’t learn this on my own though. I had help. Suddenly, the boards above him CREAK. Then BEND. Then SNA Then an ARM REACHES DOWN and PULLS Alan out of the coffin REVEAL: CHRISTOPHER MORCOM, 16, tall, pretty, and charmin ways that Alan will never, ever be.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: Christ, I thought they were going to kill you. Christopher PULLS Alan from the floorboard coffin and the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walking away from the half-finished school room, Christop helps Alan as he hobbles.  20.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG ALAN
dialogues.text: It’s not my fault. The carrots got in with the peas. (off Christopher’s look) I’m sorry. I won’t let them do it again.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: They’re getting worse.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG ALAN
dialogues.text: They only beat me up because I’m smarter than they are.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: No. They beat you up because you’re different. So you'll have to try a little harder to blend in.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG ALAN
dialogues.text: Mother says I’m just an odd duck.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: And she’s right. Alan STUMBLES and Christopher grabs his hand, steadying h

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But you know, sometimes it is the very people who no one imagines anything of who do the things that no one can imagine.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Christopher helped.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Detective Nock sits at his desk, yelling incredulously in his telephone.

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE NOCK
dialogues.text: What do you mean, “classified”? (beat) ».. Yes, I am aware of the literal meaning of the word “classified,” what I’m asking is why would a maths professor have his military records classified? (beat) . Well then I will come down there and...  21. Nock HANGS UP, frustrated. He notices Sergeant Staehl walking past. DETECTIVE NOCK (CONT’D) Come with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Detective Nock and Sergeant Staehl walk through Mancheste away from the police station.

dialogues.speaker: SGT. STAEHL
dialogues.text: ++. SO are you going to catch this mysterious thief who hasn’t actually stolen anything?

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE NOCK
dialogues.text: Alan Turing is a suspect in a robbery but they won’t share a thing with the police?

dialogues.speaker: SGT. STAEHL
dialogues.text: “Suspect”? I distinctly recall writing his name next to the word “victim.” Nock looks around, paying no attention to Staehl. He sees something (which we don’t) in the reflection of a shop window.

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE NOCK
dialogues.text: Will?

dialogues.speaker: SGT. STAEHL
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE NOCK
dialogues.text: I’m terribly sorry about this. Suddenly, Nock PUSHES Staehl, hard. Staehl, reeling, is very, very confused.

dialogues.speaker: SGT. STAEHL
dialogues.text: What? Nock responds by PUNCHING Staehl across the jaw, sending to the ground. People on the street TURN and STARE. Nock RUNS away down the street —  22. Staehl starts CHASING AFTER HIM — — They each DODGE PASSERSBY, who are all staring — — Until Nock suddenly CHANGES DIRECTIONS and SLAMS INTO A PEDESTRIAN — — The Pedestrian and Nock TUMBLE TO THE GROUND. The two SCRAMBLE, and then exchange a look: The Pedestria is... Concerned. The Pedestrian STRUGGLES TO HIS FEET and RUNS OFF. Nock stands dusting himself off as Staehl catches up to h — And PUNCHES NOCK IN THE JAW.

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE NOCK
dialogues.text: Oww! Would you stop it?

dialogues.speaker: SGT. STAEHL
dialogues.text: What is wrong with you?

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE NOCK
dialogues.text: Here. Nock hands a BILLFOLD back to Staehl.

dialogues.speaker: SGT. STAEHL
dialogues.text: Whose is this? Very confused, Staehl LOOKS THROUGH the billfold.

dialogues.speaker: SGT. STAEHL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ++. That man you knocked over! You stole his billfold. Nock shrugs. SGT. STAEHL (CONT’D) Oh. Bob?

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE NOCK
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: SGT. STAEHL
dialogues.text: There’s a photograph of you. Staehl shows Nock the billfold’s contents: A PHOTO OF NOC PAPERS WITH NOCK’S ADDRESS, PERSONAL DATA.

dialogues.speaker: SGT. STAEHL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That man was following you.  23.

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE NOCK
dialogues.text: Has been for awhile now.

dialogues.speaker: SGT. STAEHL
dialogues.text: Good God... Your home address, your district, your... Bob, there is a letter here from the Foreign Office. Staehl shows him: The letter, stamped with the Foreign Of seal, instructs that the bearer be granted access to all records concerning one “ROBERT NOCK"”.

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE PEDESTRIAN
dialogues.text: (approaching them) — Are you two all right?

dialogues.speaker: SGT. STAEHL
dialogues.text: (to Pedestrian) Bugger off. She LEAVES, offended. SGT. STAEHL (CONT’D) Why are you being followed? We have to call this in.

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE NOCK
dialogues.text: (looking at the letter) I think I might have a better idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: QUICK SHOTS: Nock PAINTS TIPP-EX over his own name on the letter he just stole, and TYPES IN A NEW ONE — “ALAN TURI

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Detective Nock walks up to a SECRETARY.

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE NOCK
dialogues.text: (to Secretary) Pardon me. I'd like to see some documents, if I may. Service records of a Mr. Turing. Alan. He FLASHES THE FORGED LETTER. DETECTIVE NOCK (CONT’D) Foreign Office sent me.  24. Off of Nock’s SMILE we

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: EXT. ATLANTIC OCEAN - GERMAN PLANE - DAY — 1940

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The game was quite a simple one.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE ATLANTIC
dialogues.text: — A GERMAN SPYPLANE spots a BRITISH CONVOY travelling acr the ocean, far away. We hear the BEEP BEEP of Morse Code the SPYPLANE SENDS OUT AN ENCRYPTED MESSAGE and we cut to

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: — The DECK of one of the British ships. A SEAMAN smokes a cigarette as waves crash against the side. He’s approache two FRIENDS. He looks: He’s only got one smoke left. In a kind gesture, he SNAPS his cigarette in half, sharing it

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. GERMAN SUBMARINE
dialogues.text: — As underwater, a GERMAN SUBMARINE receives the BEEP BEE the Morse message about the convoy’s location. The sub CHANGES COURSE —

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Every single German message. Every surprise attack. Every bombing run. Every imminent U-boat assault. They were all floating through the air, radio signals that any schoolboy with an AM kit could intercept.

dialogues.speaker: AT BLETCHLEY PARK
dialogues.text: — Inside HUT 14: ROW after ROW of RADIO STATIONS, all sta by the smartly dressed young ladies of the Women’s Royal Navy. One WREN, listening to Morse code on her headphones intercepts the very same BEEP BEEP of the MESSAGE —

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The trick was that they were encrypted. — She takes it down by hand: It’s GIBBERISH. Encrypted. S places the messages in a PILE —  25. — A FEMALE ASSISTANT picks up the pile of encrypted messa

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: — And carries it through Bletchley — — The grounds surrounding the mansion at Bletchley Park a now littered with 18 WOODEN “HUTS” — hastily constructed structures that contain all of Britain’s top secret cryptography operations —

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: One hundred and fifty nine million million million possible Enigma settings. All we had to do was try each one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: — The Female Assistant hurries past ARMED GUARDS and SECU CHECKPOINTS into —

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: — HUT 8: Where the Enigma cryptanalysis team does their w

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: But if we had 10 men checking one setting a minute, for 24 hours every day and seven days every week, it would take... Well, you tell me. How many days would it take to check each of the settings? — John Cairncross, Peter Hilton, Keith Furman, and Charle Richards use PERFORATED SHEETS to analyze Enigma messages the Female Assistant deposits the pile onto Hugh Alexande desk. All around Hut 8, we see STACK after STACK of encrypted messages, just like the one that was just delivered.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Would you like a hint? It’s not days. It’s years. The team does their best to decrypt these stacks of messa but they’re getting nowhere. There are thousands of messa and only four cryptographers.  26.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: (sighs) Oh dear, you still haven’t worked it out, have you? Pity you didn’t pay more attention in school. (beat) It’s 20 million years. MOVE IN on the urgent message about the attack, which is untouched as —

dialogues.speaker: BACK IN THE ATLANTIC
dialogues.text: — The deck of the British ship. The sailors SMOKE as we —

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: To stop a coming attack, we would have to check 20 million years worth of settings... In 20 minutes. — Move DOWN INTO THE WATER to see that the German submari has arrived. It FIRES A TORPEDO at the helpless convoy an cut—

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO HUT 8
dialogues.text: The team is still buried in pile after pile of undecrypte messages. Another convoy has been lost because they could move fast enough, and they’re so far behind they don’t ev know it yet.

dialogues.speaker: PETER HILTON
dialogues.text: I’m famished. Hugh stretches, staring out the window, where he sees a W passing by.

dialogues.speaker: HUGH ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: (cre: the WREN) Good God, what is it with women in little hats? John, Peter, Keith and Charles all look as well — there i fact something strangely sexy about women in little hats. John Cairncross gets up and walks into the next room, whe he finds Alan, working alone.  27.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN CAIRNCROSS
dialogues.text: The boys. We were going to get some lunch? (Alan ignores him) Alan?

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN CAIRNCROSS
dialogues.text: I said we were going to get some lunch? (Alan keeps ignoring him) Alan?

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN CAIRNCROSS
dialogues.text: Can you hear me?

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN CAIRNCROSS
dialogues.text: I said we’re off to get some lunch. (silence) This is starting to get a bit repetitive.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: What is?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN CAIRNCROSS
dialogues.text: I had asked if you wanted to have lunch with us.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: No you didn’t. You told me you were getting lunch.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN CAIRNCROSS
dialogues.text: Have I offended you in some way?

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: Why would you think that?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN CAIRNCROSS
dialogues.text: Would you like to come to lunch with us?

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: When is lunchtime?  28.

dialogues.speaker: HUGH ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: (calling out) Christ, Alan, it’s a bleeding sandwich.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: What is?

dialogues.speaker: HUGH ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: Lunch.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: I don’t like sandwiches.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN CAIRNCROSS
dialogues.text: Nevermind.

dialogues.speaker: HUGH ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: John was trying to be nice.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: How?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN CAIRNCROSS
dialogues.text: Let it go.

dialogues.speaker: HUGH ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: You know to pull off this irascible genius routine, one has to actually be a genius. Yet we’re the ones making progress here, aren’t we?

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: You have?

dialogues.speaker: HUGH ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: We've decrypted a number of German messages by analyzing the frequency of letter distribution.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: Oh. Even a broken clock is right twice a day. That’s not progress at all, that’s just blind luck. I’m designing a machine that will allow us to break every message, every day, instantly. We see his work: ELECTRICAL SCHEMATICS. He’s designing a STRANGE NEW MACHINE. ON THE TEAM: A machine? That’s ridiculous.

dialogues.speaker: PETER HILTON
dialogues.text: Who’s hungry? Let’s go.  29.

dialogues.speaker: HUGH ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: Bye, Alan. The guys gather their things and walk out...

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: I’m hungry. They turn.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN CAIRNCROSS
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: Peter asked if anyone was hungry. I am. (they stare at him) May I have some soup, please?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hugh, John, Peter, Keith and Charles all exit Hut 8, shak their heads and laughing at what an impossible weirdo Ala is. In the window, we see Alan’s face, alone with his work. ON ALAN: He looks out at the team, a slight longing to be among them, and yet the resolution that he never can be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alan runs for miles and miles along the outskirts of Bletchley. He thinks when he runs. It focuses him. He looks intent, deeply concentrating as he presses his legs as hard as they’1ll go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alan obsessively works on something in Hut 8, filling she after sheet of paper with his designs. He’s drawing SCHEMATICS... As it fills out, we see what it is: It’s a HUGE MACHINE.  30.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alan walks through the camp brandishing a PIECE OF PAPER. He’s a fish out of water amidst all of the MILITARY MEN moving supplies around him. He finds what he’s looking for: Commander Denniston stands before a SUPPLY TRUCK, checkin the manifest as supplies are UNLOADED.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: This is unacceptable.

dialogues.speaker: COMMANDER DENNISTON
dialogues.text: Turing. If you’d like to discuss the complaint, I’d suggest making a proper appointment with my office.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: Complaint? Hugh Alexander has denied my requisition. Parts and equipment, to build the machine I’ve designed.

dialogues.speaker: COMMANDER DENNISTON
dialogues.text: Your fellow codebreakers are refusing to work with you. They’ve filed a formal complaint.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: It’s inspired by an old Polish code machine, only infinitely more advanced.

dialogues.speaker: COMMANDER DENNISTON
dialogues.text: If you don’t respond to the complaint, I’ll have to take it up with the Home Office.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: Fine. My response is, they are all idiots. Fire them and use the savings to fund my machine. I’1l only need about a hundred thousand pounds.

dialogues.speaker: COMMANDER DENNISTON
dialogues.text: A hundred thousand — Why are you building a machine?

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: It’s highly technical. You wouldn’t understand.  31.

dialogues.speaker: COMMANDER DENNISTON
dialogues.text: I suggest you make an effort to try.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: ++. Enigma is a machine. A very well-designed machine. Our problem is that we’re trying to beat it with men. What if only a machine can defeat another machine? Denniston stares at him.

dialogues.speaker: COMMANDER DENNISTON
dialogues.text: .».. Hugh Alexander is in charge of your unit and if he’s said no, that’s that.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: I do not have time for this —

dialogues.speaker: COMMANDER DENNISTON
dialogues.text: — Have you ever won a war before, Turing? I have. Do you know how it’s done? Order. Discipline. Chain of command. You’re not at University any longer. You are a very small cog in a very large system and you’ll do as your commanding officer instructs.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: Who is your commanding officer?

dialogues.speaker: COMMANDER DENNISTON
dialogues.text: Winston Churchill. 10 Downing Street, London. You have a problem with my decision you can take it up with him. And with that, Denniston walks away, furious. ON ALAN: Well alright, if you say so...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stewart Menzies walks out of the Bletchley’s MAIN GATE, through security, when’s he’s approached by:

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: Mr. Menzies! You’re headed back to London, yes?

dialogues.speaker: STEWART MENZIES
dialogues.text: Possibly.  32.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: Will you deliver a letter for me? Alan hands Menzies a letter: It’s addressed to “WINSTON CHURCHILL. 10 DOWNING ST. LOND ON MENZIES: Well, this should be interesting... INT. BLETCHLEY PARK - DENNISTON’S OFFICE - DAY The team — Alan, Hugh, John, Peter, Keith, and Charles — assembled in Commander Denniston’s office for a meeting. Stewart Menzies watches quietly from the corner, as is hi way.

dialogues.speaker: HUGH ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: You must be joking. Churchill put Alan in charge?!?!?!

dialogues.speaker: KEITH FURMAN
dialogues.text: -— This is a terrible plan —

dialogues.speaker: PETER HILTON
dialogues.text: — No no no no no no —

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: — Really? I can give these men orders now?

dialogues.speaker: COMMANDER DENNISTON
dialogues.text: Though I hate to say it... Yes.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: Fantastic. (to Keith and Charles) Keith and Charles. You’re both fired.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH FURMAN
dialogues.text: Excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES RICHARDS
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: You're mediocre linguists and positively poor codebreakers.

dialogues.speaker: HUGH ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: Alan, you can’t just fire Keith and Charles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He just said I could.

dialogues.speaker: COMMANDER DENNISTON
dialogues.text: (furious) I did no such thing.

dialogues.speaker: STEWART MENZIES
dialogues.text: But Churchill did. Denniston looks at Menzies, stewing, but Menzies back: “What would you have me do?”

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES RICHARDS
dialogues.text: (to Alan) Go to hell. Charles and Keith leave, pissed.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN CAIRNCROSS
dialogues.text: This is inhuman. Even for you. ON DENNISTON: He looks at Alan with a withering, glare. 33. just shrugs simmering ON ALAN: He doesn’t budge an inch, or feel the slightest to explain himself. As everyone stares at him, angry, the tension is brutal.

dialogues.speaker: STEWART MENZIES
dialogues.text: (to Alan) ++. Popular at school, were you?

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Alan, Hugh, John and Peter walk back into Hut 8 after the meeting — resigned, unhappily, to their fate.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN CAIRNCROSS
dialogues.text: «+. So what do we do now?

dialogues.speaker: PETER HILTON
dialogues.text: We're short on staff.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: We get more staff.

dialogues.speaker: HUGH ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: And how are you going to do that? Alan takes a paper from his desk and TACKS IT UP ON THE W  34. ON THE PAPER: It’s a CROSSWORD PUZZLE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A MAN opens up that morning’s Daily Telegraph, and flippi through the paper, he sees an advertisement. ON THE AD: It’s a crossword puzzle. Below it, the ad copy says — “If you can solve this puzzle in under ten minutes please call STO-6264 for an exciting career opportunity.”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SERIES OF SHOTS: Other people — MEN, WOMEN, STUDENTS, RETIREES — open up their papers and see Alan’s ad. They a try solving the puzzle. It’s really, really hard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back in the first house, the Man is trying to complete th puzzle when — — The AIR RAID SIREN goes off. Quickly, the Man gathers his FAMILY and they rush down in

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Man and his WIFE light candles in the safety of their underground BOMB SHELTER. As BOMBS EXPLODE on the street above them, the Man passes TOYS and GAMES to his children, to keep them distracted during the assault. He returns to Alan’s crossword puzzle, trying to solve it just a few yards above him a city burnt to rubble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CIVILIANS run down into an old TUBE TUNNEL to get away fr the bombing. Inside the tightly crowded station, some people read book some play games, some lay on the train tracks to sleep as dust POOFS UP from the shaking ground.  35. Normal life goes on as the LIGHTS FLICKER from the shelli above. By the dim flickering, we see OTHER PEOPLE trying their h at Alan’s puzzle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alan bicycles through London, passing a group of GASMASKE SCHOOLCHILDREN being led calmly on a DRILL by their TEACH As a MILKMAN crosses a BOMBED OUT BUILDING to delivers hi wares, Alan comes to a stop beside a MARRIED COUPLE who a digging through the RUBBLE. The husband digs while the wi rests, sipping tea as if her house was other than a war z While FIREMEN tend to a nearby smoldering mess, Alan lock his bike and enters MI-6 HEADQUARTERS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alan and Stewart Menzies talk in the hallway, outside a closed door.

dialogues.speaker: STEWART MENZIES
dialogues.text: Who are they?

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: All sorts, really. A school teacher. An engineer. A handful of students.

dialogues.speaker: STEWART MENZIES
dialogues.text: And you think they’re qualified for Bletchley because they’re good at crossword puzzles?

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: Well, they say they’re good. Now we should probably find out. Alan leads Menzies into:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alan and Stewart Menzies are in an MI-6 conference room. been set up like a class room: Rows of identical desks, a which sit a COLLECTION OF CROSSWORD ENTHUSIASTS. There ar around 20, all men.  Just then, 36.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: ++. You'll have six minutes to complete the puzzle, at which point— a WOMAN enters. Everyone turns to look.. Her name is JOAN CLARKE, 20s, a graduate student at Cambr who’s trying to get as far away from her preacher father possible, story. and she’s about to become very important to this

dialogues.speaker: MI-6 AGENT
dialogues.text: Pardon, Ma’am, this room is restricted.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN CLARKE
dialogues.text: Apologies for my tardiness — bus caught a flat tire.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: (irritated) May I continue, please?

dialogues.speaker: MI-6 AGENT
dialogues.text: (to Joan) You’re not allowed in here, Ma’am.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN CLARKE
dialogues.text: I’m only a few minutes late. With the bombing there’s ten potholes to each road.

dialogues.speaker: MI-6 AGENT
dialogues.text: No, ma’am, the secretaries are to head upstairs. This room is for the candidates.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: May I please get on with this?

dialogues.speaker: JOAN CLARKE
dialogues.text: I am a candidate.

dialogues.speaker: MI-6 AGENT
dialogues.text: For what position?

dialogues.speaker: JOAN CLARKE
dialogues.text: The letter did not say, precisely.

dialogues.speaker: MI-6 AGENT
dialogues.text: Yes, so, secretaries are to head upstairs.  37.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN CLARKE
dialogues.text: It said it was top secret.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: (comes over to them) What is going on here?

dialogues.speaker: JOAN CLARKE
dialogues.text: There was a crossword in the paper. I solved it. I got a letter saying I was a candidate for some mysterious job. So here I am. My name is Joan Clarke. She hands the Agent the LETTER.

dialogues.speaker: MI-6 AGENT
dialogues.text: Miss, did you really solve this puzzle yourself?

dialogues.speaker: JOAN CLARKE
dialogues.text: What makes you think I couldn’t have solved the puzzle myself? I am quite —

dialogues.speaker: MI-6 AGENT
dialogues.text: — Ma’am I'll have to ask you —

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: — Miss Clarke. I find tardiness unacceptable under any circumstance. Now take a seat, so we may continue. Joan stares at Alan: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN CLARKE
dialogues.text: Apologies again for being late. As Joan SITS, the Agent turns to Menzies — who’s been silently observing Alan thus far — for support. Menzies SHRUGS. The Agent backs down. Alan passes out NEW CROSSWORD PUZZLES.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN CLARKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: — Pardon, but before we start, can you tell me a bit about this position I’m qualifying for?

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: Oh for God’s sake — No.  38.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN CLARKE
dialogues.text: It’s just that I’ve a pretty decent job at the University, and I'd rather not give it up for something less interesting.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: Miss Clarke. You now have the distinct honor of having wasted more of my time than any other person in this room. Quiet. Gentlemen. And lady. You have six minutes. Begin.

dialogues.speaker: SHOTS
dialogues.text: As they work:

dialogues.speaker: STEWART MENZIES
dialogues.text: (whispering to Alan) Six minutes? Is that even possible?

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: No. It takes me eight. But this test isn’t about crosswords — it’s about how you approach solving an impossible problem. Do you take the whole thing at once? Do you divide it into smaller — — Suddenly, Joan sits up. She’s finished. Early. ALAN TURING (CONT’D) You've finished?

dialogues.speaker: JOAN CLARKE
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: (checking watch) ».. 5 minutes, 34 seconds.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN CLARKE
dialogues.text: You said to do it in under 6. ON ALAN: The smartest man in the room is surprised for th first time in a very long time by someone who might be ev smarter.

dialogues.speaker: STEWART MENZIES
dialogues.text: (to Alan) Seems like some people approach it by simply doing the impossible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Minutes later, TWO PEOPLE have survived the crossword tes Joan is one of them.

dialogues.speaker: STEWART MENZIES
dialogues.text: Congratulations, and my warmest welcome to His Majesty’s service. If you speak a word of anything I’m about to show you, you’ll be executed for High Treason. You will lie to your friends, your family, everyone you meet about what it is you really do.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN CLARKE
dialogues.text: And what is it that we’re really doing?

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: We're going to break an unbreakable Nazi code and win the war.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN CLARKE
dialogues.text: Well that does sound more interesting than my university job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Young Alan and Christopher sit under a tree, the school i the distance. Alan is going through a crossword puzzle, Christopher is reading a book. Their legs are touching affectionately without either even knowing, like two people who are effortlessly comfortable with one another.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG ALAN
dialogues.text: What’s that you’re reading? Christopher shows him: “A Guide to Codes and Cyphers.”

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: It’s about cryptography.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG ALAN
dialogues.text: What’s cryptography?

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: It’s complicated. You wouldn’t understand.  40.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG ALAN
dialogues.text: I’m only fourteen months younger than you. Don’t treat me like a child.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: Cryptography is the science of codes.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG ALAN
dialogues.text: Like secret messages?

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: Not secret. That’s the brilliant part. Messages that anyone can see, but no one knows what they mean, unless you have the key.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG ALAN
dialogues.text: (confused) How is that different from talking?

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: Talking?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG ALAN
dialogues.text: When people talk to each other they never say what they mean. They say something else. And you’re supposed to just know what they mean. Only, I never do. So how is that different?

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: (handing him the book) Alan, I have a funny feeling that you're going to be very good at this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christopher walks Young Alan back to his dormitory. They’ happy after a long day together.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: Goodnight, Alan. Christopher touches Alan’s shoulder, and the two share a sweet moment.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: Goodnight.  41. Alan watches Christopher go; his heart is blooming, in lo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A crowded POLICE STATION. Detective Nock approaches his boss, SUPERINTENDANT SMITH, the latter walks through the station dropping PAPERS onto various DESKS and checking the work of other POLICE OFFIC Nock hands Superintendant Smith a MANILA ENVELOPE.

dialogues.speaker: SUPERINTENDANT SMITH
dialogues.text: What is this?

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE NOCK
dialogues.text: Alan Turing’s classified military file.

dialogues.speaker: SUPERINTENDANT SMITH
dialogues.text: (displays the file) It’s bloody empty.

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE NOCK
dialogues.text: Exactly.

dialogues.speaker: SUPERINTENDANT SMITH
dialogues.text: It’s an empty manila envelope.

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE NOCK
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: SUPERINTENDANT SMITH
dialogues.text: Well you’ve cracked the case wide open then, haven't you?

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE NOCK
dialogues.text: Alan Turing’s war records aren’t just classified. They're non- existent. That means someone got rid of them. Erased them, burned them.

dialogues.speaker: SUPERINTENDANT SMITH
dialogues.text: And that person broke into his house and stole... Nothing?

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE NOCK
dialogues.text: What if Turing wasn’t just a math professor?  42.

dialogues.speaker: SUPERINTENDANT SMITH
dialogues.text: You think maybe he also teaches English lit?

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE NOCK
dialogues.text: Guy Burgess and Donald Maclean.

dialogues.speaker: SUPERINTENDANT SMITH
dialogues.text: The spies? From the papers?

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE NOCK
dialogues.text: The Soviet spies. But first, they were professors, weren’t they? Newspapers say they became radicalized at Cambridge. Then they joined the Communist Party, took positions in the Foreign Office and leaked information to Stalin during the war. Now, can you think of anyone else we know who was at Cambridge, then took up something murky and top secret when the war broke out? Smith gives him a look.

dialogues.speaker: SUPERINTENDANT SMITH
dialogues.text: You think Alan Turing might be a Soviet agent? ON NOCK’S FACE: It would explain a lot, wouldn’t it? ON SUPERINTENDANT SMITH: He’s considering...

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE NOCK
dialogues.text: Something very serious is happening, right here under our noses. Wouldn’t you like to find out what it is? Smith thinks, and then hands the folder back to Nock.

dialogues.speaker: SUPERINTENDANT SMITH
dialogues.text: No. I wouldn’t. I like my job. Now as to yours: Those lads have been causing a ruckus down by Whitworth Park again. Will you give them a talking to? Thank you. And with that, Smith leaves. ON NOCK: Damn it. He walks back across the station to find Sergeant Staehl waiting beside his desk.  43.

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT STAEHL
dialogues.text: Well? What’d he say?

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE NOCK
dialogues.text: He said alright. Let’s do it. Let’s follow Turing. You’ll take the first shift. Turing won’t have a secret left by the time we’re through with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON: A GIANT, HALF-BUILT MACHINE. The size of a dini room table, but taller than it is wide, its guts are comp of SPINNING GEARS and a seemingly endless stream of LONG WIRES. REVEAL: TECHNICIANS work on putting the machine together, SOLDERING THE WIRES, while Alan FUSSES.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: Careful! Damn it, will you — It’s not a toy. Alan tries to protect his precious creation when he’s interrupted by:

dialogues.speaker: HUGH ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: Alan! Your new minion has arrived. Alan turns to see: His new recruit, JACK GOOD. ++. But no Joan.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: (displeased) ... Where’s Miss Clarke?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joan returns home from the market when she hears a famili VOICE from the sitting room.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: — Well it’s a very important radio factory you see. It’s not really — I mean along the spectrum of radio factories this one is particularly— Joan follows the voices to find:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alan sitting across from her MOTHER and FATHER, arguing. ALAN TURING (CONT’D) (seeing Joan) Hello. Joan makes the sort of face any young woman would make if found Alan Turing sitting to tea with her parents.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the KITCHEN: Joan's MOTHER hands her a TEA TRAY. The t share a look. As Joan’s Mother and Father pretend to putter in the kitc listening in on the conversation in the next room, Joan t the tray to the LIVING ROOM, where she begins to serve te

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: ++. Why aren’t you at Bletchley?

dialogues.speaker: JOAN CLARKE
dialogues.text: ("My parents can hear us”) So kind of you to visit, Mr. Turing. Was your trip pleasant?

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: Gather your things and let’s go.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN CLARKE
dialogues.text: I’m sorry. I am unable to accept your offer.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: And why not?

dialogues.speaker: JOAN CLARKE
dialogues.text: As my father told you, it is felt — well we feel — that such a position would hardly be appropriate.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: You earned a double-first in mathematics.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN CLARKE
dialogues.text: But sadly was not granted the opportunity to become a Fellow.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: You belong at Bletchley.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN CLARKE
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, but for someone in my position to work - to live - amongst all of your men, so far from home It would be indecorous.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: What in the world does that even —

dialogues.speaker: JOAN CLARKE
dialogues.text: ("I told you they’re listening!”) — One lump or two? Are you fucking serious? Yes. I’m fucking serious. He tries to think of a solution

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: ++. We have a group of young women who tend to our clerical tasks. Assistants, translators. They live together in town. Would that be a more suitable environment? ON JOAN’S PARENTS: This sounds more promising.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN CLARKE
dialogues.text: So I would be working amongst these women?

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: ("Not actually”) Yes. “Go on.” ALAN TURING (CONT’D) ++. Wonderful ladies, they even organize social events at St Martin’s church, down the road. The whole thing is really quite... Decorous. PARENTS: That’s much better.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN CLARKE
dialogues.text: ("Good job.”) Well. I will have to talk this over with my family. As Joan’s parents enter, we

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joan walks Alan out of the front door, finally out of ear from her parents for a few quick seconds.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: You won’t have the proper clearance, so we’ll have to improvise a bit.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN CLARKE
dialogues.text: Why are you helping me?

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: There is only one thing that matters in this entire world, do you understand? Breaking Enigma.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN CLARKE
dialogues.text: Mr. Turing. Why are you helping me?

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: ++. Sometimes it is the very people who no one imagines anything of who do the things that no one can imagine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joan and a few OTHER WRENS exit a BUS that’s deposited th in front of the Park’s central mansion. Looking up at it, she sees Alan walking across the way. He gives her a small wave, which she returns with a small wave back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Later in Hut 8, the team (w/o Alan) — Hugh, John, Peter, the new guy, Jack — work frantically into the night. The team uses their PERFORATED SHEETS to find linguistic patterns in the Enigma messages, everyone working as hard as fast as they possibly can until — — Suddenly a BELL GOES OFF. Everyone stops their work, frustrated. Angry, Hugh KICKS his desk.  47.

dialogues.speaker: JACK GOOD
dialogues.text: ++. What just happened?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN CAIRNCROSS
dialogues.text: Midnight. All the work we did today is useless. But don’t worry: We've a few hours before tomorrow's messages start pouring in. And we start all over again.

dialogues.speaker: PETER HILTON
dialogues.text: From scratch.

dialogues.speaker: HUGH ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: I am sick of this. Sick. He made me waste four hours this morning re- wiring his plugboard matrix. Three hours yesterday on rotor positions.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN CAIRNCROSS
dialogues.text: Don’t go over there.

dialogues.speaker: HUGH ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: No. If our job was not impossible before it bloody well is now. Hugh stands and heads to the door —

dialogues.speaker: JOHN CAIRNCROSS
dialogues.text: — Hugh, don’t — — But Hugh is already gone to

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alan stands alone with his machine, tinkering, comparing assembly to his SCHEMATICS. Hugh BURSTS in —

dialogues.speaker: HUGH ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: — Damn you and damn your useless machine.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: (not even looking) My machine is how we’re going to win.

dialogues.speaker: HUGH ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: This machine?  48. Hugh grabs a GLASS from the table and SMASHES IT AGAINST ALAN'S MACHINE.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: (turning around, shocked) Stop.

dialogues.speaker: HUGH ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: This is the bloody machine you’re talking about? He grabs a WRENCH — — Alan moves to protect Christopher, standing between Hug and the machine —

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: No no don’t — — When the team enters behind Hugh — — GRABBING HIM and HOLDING HIM BACK. Alan stands between the team and his machine as Hugh STEA

dialogues.speaker: HUGH ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: ++. You could help us. You could make this go faster. But you won't.

dialogues.speaker: PETER HILTON
dialogues.text: Hugh is right, Alan. There are actual soldiers out there trying to win an actual war — my brother, my cousins, all my friends, they are all making a difference, while we wile away our days producing nothing. Because of you.

dialogues.speaker: HUGH ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: Because of you... Hugh PUSHES towards Alan again — — but John HOLDS HIM BACK.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN CAIRNCROSS
dialogues.text: (to Hugh, calming) ... What’s the use?

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: My machine will work. Hugh stares Alan, then at John.

dialogues.speaker: HUGH ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: +++. I’m going to the pub.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hugh leaves, and the team FOLLOWS.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: «+. It’ll work. ON ALAN: Alone. Rattled from the violence. Scared. And yet... Resolved. He makes a fateful decision and runs off to

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alan goes back into Hut 8, which is now empty. He goes to a far STORAGE CABINET, from which he removes a STACK OF ENIGMA MESSAGES. Alan FOLDS THE SHEETS, STUFFING THEM INTO HIS COAT POCKET — INTO HIS PANTS — — INTO HIS SHOES — — ETC. He runs out, concealing enough top secret information on body to have him hanged for treason ten times over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alan walks his bicycle through the CHECK POINT, showing h ID to the GUARDS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the Gate, ARMED GUARDS stop him as he passes, and as i protocol, Alan opens up his BRIEFCASE for the men to see: Nothing is inside. Concealing the documents in his coat/pants/shoes/etc., Al hops on his bike and heads off to: EXT. JOAN’S FLAT - LATER Alan bicycles to the outside of Joan’s new flat. The windows are BOARDED UP at night — city regulations, s that the Germans flying overhead can’t see any lights fro the town.  50. Alan CHUCKS A SMALL rock at Joan's boarded window — — Then carefully sneaks around in back of the house— — Finding an OPEN BACK WINDOW — — On the second floor. He CLIMBS A NEARBY FENCE, and JUMPS FROM THE FENCE TO THE WINDOW — — Where Joan GRABS HIM and HELPS HIM INSIDE: INT. JOAN’S FLAT - CONTINUOUS It’s dark inside...

dialogues.speaker: JOAN CLARKE
dialogues.text: (whispering) Could you have made a bit more noise, Alan? Not sure you woke up my landlady.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: Sorry. Joan turns on a SMALL LAMP and then lights some CANDLES.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN CLARKE
dialogues.text: The best I can do. No male visitors after dark. She watches Alan remove papers from his pockets.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN CLARKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What’d you bring me? Alan produces the Enigma messages from every available hi place on his person.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN CLARKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ++. Some men try flowers, you know.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: (pulling papers from inside his shirt) These are actual decrypted Enigma messages, direct from Nazi high command.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN CLARKE
dialogues.text: Or chocolates. Girls like chocolate.  51. Alan starts PLACING THE MESSAGES down on a table, but the isn’t room, so he starts LAYING THEM OUT ON THE FLOOR.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN CLARKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (reading a message) “0600 hours. Weather today is clear. Rain in the evening. Heil Hitler.” Well, clearly that vital information is going to win us the war.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: It’s the relationship between the encrypted and decrypted messages that interests me. Is there a clue there that we can build into Christopher?

dialogues.speaker: JOAN CLARKE
dialogues.text: Who’s “Christopher”?

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: Oh. He’s my machine.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN CLARKE
dialogues.text: You named him?

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: Is that a bad name?

dialogues.speaker: JOAN CLARKE
dialogues.text: Nevermind... (looks over the messages) Are you trying to build your Universal Machine? Alan looks at her: How do you know what that is? Joan smiles.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN CLARKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I read your paper at university.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: They're teaching it already?

dialogues.speaker: JOAN CLARKE
dialogues.text: Oh God no, but I was precocious. You theorized a machine that can solve any problem. It doesn’t just do one thing: It does everything. The machine isn’t only programmable, it’s re-programmable. ON ALAN: She understands what he’s been writing about.  52.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN CLARKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Is that part of the idea behind your Christopher?

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: Human beings can compute large sums very quickly. Even Hugh can do that. I want Christopher to be... Smarter. To make a calculation, and then to determine what to do next. Like a person does. Think of it: An electrical brain. A digital computer.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN CLARKE
dialogues.text: (trying out the words on her tongue) A “digital computer?” Hmm.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: I’ll show you — — Alan TURNS, and KNOCKS OVER THE CANDLE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Which LIGHTS THE ENIGMA MESSAGES ON FIRE. Alan and Joan SCRAMBLE TO PUT OUT THE FIRE. They make a lot of NOISE in the process, though they do Manage not to burn down Joan’s flat. ALAN TURING (CONT’D) I’m so sorry. They hear more noise from downstairs: “Joan?!? HELLO?!?”

dialogues.speaker: JOAN CLARKE
dialogues.text: My landlady. You need to leave.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: Right. Alan moves to the front door —

dialogues.speaker: JOAN CLARKE
dialogues.text: — No. The window. She’s coming.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: (staring at window) Really?

dialogues.speaker: JOAN CLARKE
dialogues.text: Go.  53. Alan AWKWARDLY CLIMBS OUT THE WINDOW, TRYING NOT TO FALL.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REVEAL: Alan has been injured in his fall. (Climbing is not his strong suit.) Alan walks through the grounds into:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alan enters Hut 8 to find his team watching silently as a bunch of MILITARY POLICE RIFLE THROUGH HIS DESK — — MANHANDLING his papers, his machine parts, making a mes

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: (re: parts of Christopher) Hey! Don’t touch that! The RMP’S TRAIN GUNS ON HIM.

dialogues.speaker: MILITARY POLICEMAN
dialogues.text: Don’t move!

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: That’s my desk.

dialogues.speaker: COMMANDER DENNISTON, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Thank goodness. Be a pity if we were searching the wrong one. Alan turns to find Denniston directing the search.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: COMMANDER DENNISTON
dialogues.text: There’s a spy at Bletchley Park.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN CAIRNCROSS
dialogues.text: The Navy thinks one of us is a Soviet double-agent, Alan.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: Why?  54.

dialogues.speaker: COMMANDER DENNISTON
dialogues.text: Our boys intercepted this on its way to Moscow. Look familiar? Denniston hands Alan a TELEGRAM — it’s a LONG STRING OF LETTERS, running down the entire page.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: (looking at the telegram) . This is a Beale Cypher. It’s encrypted with a key phrase, from a book or a poem or... (re: the team) Which one of them did this? As Alan stares at the team, they stare back at him. He glances at the RMP’s rifling through his desk. Oh fuck. ALAN TURING (CONT’D) I’m not a double agent.

dialogues.speaker: COMMANDER DENNISTON
dialogues.text: Double agents are such bastards. Isolated loners. No attachments to friends or family. Arrogant. Think they’re smart enough to get away with anything. Do you know anyone like that?

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: I know you don’t like me... But you don’t think I could actually be a spy, do you? ON THE TEAM: They won’t look him in the eye.

dialogues.speaker: MILITARY POLICEMAN
dialogues.text: (to Denniston) Nothing out of the ordinary, Sir.

dialogues.speaker: COMMANDER DENNISTON
dialogues.text: Well then. Next time, you will make a mistake. And then, I don’t even need to bother firing you — I can simply hang you for treason. Denniston and his men LEAVE.

dialogues.speaker: HUGH ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: (to Jack) Aren’t you glad you joined up just in time?  55.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the machine Hut next door, Alan touches his precious machine for comfort. Whenever he feels lonely, misunderstood, isolated — he ha his machine. There’s a KNOCK on the door and... ++. Joan enters.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN CLARKE
dialogues.text: I heard about what happened... I have an idea of what might cheer you up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alan and Joan sip from beer bottles in the “beer hut” — A the military commissaries, it’s so named because, well, i the one that serves beer. They can be a bit more relaxed here than at Joan’s flat. They’re surrounded by NAPKINS full of MATHEMATICAL EQUATI which they’re studying, debating, etc.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN CLARKE
dialogues.text: ++. So because no letter can be encoded as itself, you’ve already a handful of settings that can be rejected at the outset. If you — Just then, Hugh, John, and Peter enter the Beer Hut... ++. Alan looks up, seeing them. Joan notices.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN CLARKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Is that your team? Let’s say hello.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN CLARKE
dialogues.text: (to the boys) Over here! They see Joan...  56.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: I told you not to do that.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN CLARKE
dialogues.text: Correct. ++. Hugh, John and Peter approach.

dialogues.speaker: HUGH ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: Alan. Didn’t even know you drank.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN CLARKE
dialogues.text: He doesn’t, really, he just sort of sips at the foam.

dialogues.speaker: HUGH ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: Tell you a secret, Miss...

dialogues.speaker: JOAN CLARKE
dialogues.text: ++. Clarke.

dialogues.speaker: HUGH ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: Miss Clarke.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN CLARKE
dialogues.text: Please.

dialogues.speaker: HUGH ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: The foam’s my favorite part too.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN CLARKE
dialogues.text: Well then, I’1l show you a trick. (to Bartender) Alex! We’re in need of supplies. Joan hops behind the bar and the BARTENDER helps her to BOTTLES OF GUINNESS. Hugh, Alan, John and Peter watch.

dialogues.speaker: HUGH ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: Alan, are you... On a date?

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: What? No. Of course not.

dialogues.speaker: HUGH ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: Mind if I have a crack?

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: I’m not a Soviet spy.  Returning, 57.

dialogues.speaker: HUGH ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: Do love a proper blonde.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: Hugh. I swear. I’m not a spy.

dialogues.speaker: HUGH ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: Oh for God’s sake, Alan, of course you’re not a spy.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: HUGH ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: Denniston gave me the Beale Cypher. And guess what? I broke it. “Ask and it shall be given you; seek and ye shall find.” Matthew 7:7. That was the key. Far too simple for you. Pity Denniston disagrees. Joan POURS PINTS OF GUINNESS FOR THE TEAM.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN CLARKE
dialogues.text: Did you ever notice that the bubbles in a pint of Guinness travel downwards, as opposed to upwards in any other beer? Ever wonder why? It’s because the pint glass creates drag on the bubbles along the side; but the center bubbles are free to sprint upwards. Then the rising current in the middle pushes down on the side bubbles and... And voila: Guinness. The official beer of mathematicians. ON THE PINTS: Joan has etched pi symbols into the foam.

dialogues.speaker: HUGH ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: Be still my beating heart. Come join us for a drink.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: She’s assisting me with some calculations.

dialogues.speaker: HUGH ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: Fine, Alan can come too.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: Thank you.  58.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN CLARKE
dialogues.text: Hugh was being sarcastic.

dialogues.speaker: HUGH ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: He’s a lost cause, I promise.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN CLARKE
dialogues.text: We'll be there in a moment. Joan smiles at Hugh as he joins John and Peter at a separ table.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: ++. He likes you.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN CLARKE
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: You got him to like you.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN CLARKE
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: JOAN CLARKE
dialogues.text: Because I’m a woman in a man’s job and I don’t have the luxury of being an ass. (beat) Alan, it doesn’t matter how smart you are. Enigma is smarter. If you really want to beat it - if you really want to solve your puzzle — you're going to need all the help you can get. And they are not going to help you if they do not like you. Alan thinks. The next sentence is incredibly hard for him say out loud.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: ».. How should I get them to like me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alan enters Hut 8 to find his team hard at work. He’s carrying a BAG OF APPLES.  59.

dialogues.speaker: HUGH ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: (sees apples) What’re those?

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: Apples.

dialogues.speaker: HUGH ALEXANDER
