dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: No, they really are... I... Joan told me it’d be nice to bring you all something. Alan takes the apple bag around the room, handing each ma apple. They take them. It’s really awkward.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN CAIRNCROSS
dialogues.text: Thanks?

dialogues.speaker: PETER HILTON
dialogues.text: I like apples.

dialogues.speaker: HUGH ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: My best to Miss Clarke.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: +. There are two fellows in the woods. And they run into a bear. The first fellow, he kneels down and starts to pray. But the second one, he begins lacing up his boots. The first one says, “my friend, what’re you doing? You can’t outrun a bear.” And the second one responds, “I don’t have to. I only have to outrun you.” Ba dum bum. Awkward silence. ALAN TURING (CONT’D) I’ll be with Christopher if anyone needs me. Alan walks off to the adjacent Hut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Young Alan and Christopher are in math class.  60. The TEACHER drones on as the students pretend to pay attention. Young Alan and Christopher PASS NOTES — — Dropping them by each other’s desks — -— And snapping them up quickly.

dialogues.speaker: TEACHER
dialogues.text: Mr. Turing! Passing notes, are we?

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: No, Sir. The Teacher comes over, and grabs the note from his hand. ON THE NOTE: “FDFH RG TU HSD PDXT PEJND QERDZX.” It's encrypted.

dialogues.speaker: TEACHER
dialogues.text: (holding it up for everyone) Only Mr. Turing would pass notes written in gibberish. The other students LAUGH as the Teacher drops the note in trash. Alan isn’t bothered by the laughter — he’s safe in his private world with Christopher. The BELL RINGS. Class is over. AS EVERYONE SHUFFLES OUT:

dialogues.speaker: TEACHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Alright you lot, do not forget your calculus over break. Have a pleasant holiday and we’ll resume your integrals when you return. Alan waits... And grabs the note from the trash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now alone, Alan DECRYPTS THE MESSAGE. One at a time, the letters become intelligible. ON THE NOTE: “SEE YOU IN TWO LONG WEEKS, DEAREST FRIEND.” ON ALAN: Christopher called him his dearest friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alan and Joan eat a PICNIC LUNCH in a wooded area behind 8. Alan finishes writing an EQUATION, then hands his NOTEBOO Joan. She looks at the equation, then instantly starts CROSSING THINGS OUT and REWRITING. Alan laughs. There aren’t many people who would cross out his work so brazenly. Joan sees his laughter, looks up: “What’d I do?” But before Alan can respond they both see: Hugh approachi Alan is nervous. But Hugh simply HANDS ALAN A SHEET OF PAPER.

dialogues.speaker: HUGH ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: Look at this. As Alan and Joan stare at SCHEMATICS on the paper, Hugh SWIPES A SANDWICH from their picnic and begins to chew. HUGH ALEXANDER (CONT’D) If you run the wires across the plugboard matrix diagonally, you'll eliminate rotor positions 500 times faster.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: ++. This is actually not an entirely terrible idea.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN CLARKE
dialogues.text: That’s Alan for “thank you.”

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: (looking up) That’s my sandwich.

dialogues.speaker: HUGH ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: You don’t like sandwiches. And with that, Hugh takes another bite, gives Joan a wink and walks off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alan and the team (Hugh, John, Peter) stand in a half-cir around the now-completed Christopher.  62. An ELECTRICAL ASSISTANT feeds fresh Enigma messages into end of the machine. The men look at each other, feeling the importance of the moment.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN CAIRNCROSS
dialogues.text: (to Alan) You nervous? Alan takes a gulp and CONNECTS the final bit of electrica wiring... ... AND THE VERY FIRST “DIGITAL COMPUTER” IN HISTORY COME LIFE.

dialogues.speaker: THE WIRES.
dialogues.text: The CLACKING SOUND it makes is UNBELIEVABLY LOUD.

dialogues.speaker: PETER HILTON
dialogues.text: (yelling over the machine) Christ!! What happens now?!

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: It should tell us the day’s Enigma settings!!

dialogues.speaker: HUGH ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: How long?!? ON ALAN: He’s not sure... The team shares a look: Is this really going to work?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dawn rises over Bletchley Park. INT. BLETCHLEY PARK - DENNISTON’S OFFICE - MORNING Commander Denniston receives a visit from the Electrical Assistant who'd been helping Alan in the previous scene.

dialogues.speaker: ELECTRICAL ASSISTANT
dialogues.text: The gears just keep spinning and spinning. It’s endless.

dialogues.speaker: COMMANDER DENNISTON
dialogues.text: And there’s no result in sight?  63. The Assistant NODS. Denniston SMILES: Got him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the machine CLACKS away, Alan is frantically going ove his papers. He’s unshaven, wearing yesterday’s clothes. H hasn’t gotten a wink of sleep. ON ALAN’S FRANTIC PACING: Why isn’t it working? Why?! Alan rubs his eyes, exhausted, and as he does so he looks the window to see... .».. Commander Denniston walking towards the Machine Hut, accompanied by a HOME OFFICE MAN and TWO RMPs. Alan quickly runs to the door and BOLTS it — — Just as Denniston and the men get to it from the outsid

dialogues.speaker: OUTSIDE
dialogues.text: Denniston tries the door. It won’t open.

dialogues.speaker: COMMANDER DENNISTON
dialogues.text: Turing! Open the bloody door!

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: No!!!

dialogues.speaker: COMMANDER DENNISTON
dialogues.text: Open the door or we will break it down!!

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: I cannot let you in!! I cannot let you interfere!!!

dialogues.speaker: OUTSIDE
dialogues.text: Denniston turns to the RMPs: Break it down. The RMPs KICK DOWN THE DOOR — — And the men BURST INTO THE ROOM as Alan FALLS BACK.  64.

dialogues.speaker: COMMANDER DENNISTON
dialogues.text: (re: the horrible noise) Turn that thing off. An RMP walks over to Christopher — -— Alan tries to stop him but they POINT GUNS AT HIM — -— And so Alan watches in absolute horror as they TURN OF MACHINE.

dialogues.speaker: COMMANDER DENNISTON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Well then. It seems your great big expensive machine doesn’t work.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: It does.

dialogues.speaker: COMMANDER DENNISTON
dialogues.text: Wonderful. So you’ve broken Enigma then?

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: It works... It was just... Still working.

dialogues.speaker: COMMANDER DENNISTON
dialogues.text: This is my associate from the Home Office. A hundred thousand pounds is quite a lot of money. He’s here to see what you have to show for it.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: You will never understand the importance of what I’ve created here. Commander Denniston exchanges a look with the men: See wh mean?

dialogues.speaker: COMMANDER DENNISTON
dialogues.text: Have you decrypted any German messages? A single one? Can you point to anything at all that you've achieved? ON ALAN: He can’t.

dialogues.speaker: COMMANDER DENNISTON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Your funding is up, and our patience has expired. It is with such great pleasure that I finally get to say this: Alan Turing, you're fired.  65. ON ALAN: What can he do? This is it...

dialogues.speaker: COMMANDER DENNISTON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Please escort Mr. Turing from the premises.

dialogues.speaker: HUGH ALEXANDER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: No. Everyone turns to see Hugh, John, and Peter at the door, wearing fresh clothes.

dialogues.speaker: COMMANDER DENNISTON
dialogues.text: Pardon?

dialogues.speaker: HUGH ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: God help me... If you fire Alan, you'll have to fire me too.

dialogues.speaker: COMMANDER DENNISTON
dialogues.text: What on earth are you saying?

dialogues.speaker: HUGH ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: Trust me, no one wants to say this less than I do, but Alan’s right. His machine can work. At least it’s the best chance we’ve got.

dialogues.speaker: COMMANDER DENNISTON
dialogues.text: You must be joking.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN CAIRNCROSS
dialogues.text: If you fire them, you’ll have to fire me too.

dialogues.speaker: PETER HILTON
dialogues.text: And me.

dialogues.speaker: HUGH ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: We're the best cryptographic minds in Britain. Are you going to fire us all? Denniston looks to the Home Office Man, who NODS: Hugh is right. HUGH ALEXANDER (CONT’D) At least give us more time. Six more months, and if the machine doesn’t produce results we’ll go back to doing things the old way.

dialogues.speaker: COMMANDER DENNISTON
dialogues.text: ++. One month. And then so help me God you are all gone.  66. Denniston and his men LEAVE. The team breathes a sigh of relief: They’ve been given a temporary reprieve.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: HUGH ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: This machine better bloody work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sergeant Staehl walks eagerly through the police station. He comes to an office marked “SUPERINTENDANT SMITH”, wher OPENS the door to find INT. MANCHESTER POLICE STATION - SMITH’S OFFICE - CONTINU Superintendant Smith and Detective Nock are in the middle a genial conversation. The Superintendant turns to Staehl.

dialogues.speaker: SUPERINTENDANT SMITH
dialogues.text: Can I help you?

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT STAEHL
dialogues.text: Sirs, I think I’ve got him.

dialogues.speaker: SUPERINTENDANT SMITH
dialogues.text: Got who?

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT STAEHL
dialogues.text: Turing. Detective Nock looks at Staehl — “Shhhh!” The Superintendant looks at Nock — “You didn’t...” SERGEANT STAEHL (CONT’D) I trailed Turing to a pub last night, where he met a bloke. They exchanged an envelope. So I followed the guy, picked him up, gave him a good shake... Here, I’1l show you.  67.

dialogues.speaker: SUPERINTENDANT SMITH
dialogues.text: (to Nock, angry) You and I will discuss this later. (to Staehl) Sergeant. They follow Staehl out to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Nock and Smith stands outside the INTERROGATION ROOM, Sergeant Staehl points through the window in the door: Inside is ARNOLD MURRAY, 20s, nervous.

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT STAEHL
dialogues.text: He’s a bloody poofter. He confessed. Staehl shows Nock and Smith a SIGNED STATEMENT.

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE NOCK
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT STAEHL
dialogues.text: The man admitted it. Arnold Murray. Bit of a hustler. Hangs around that pub, men pay him for a go. Turing is one of the men who paid. Only, Mr. Murray got the bright idea to rob Turing’s house after, with a friend. That’s what Turing was hiding: He’s a poof, not a spy.

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE NOCK
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: SUPERINTENDANT SMITH
dialogues.text: This is good work, Sergeant. Quite good.

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE NOCK
dialogues.text: No, it’s not.

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT STAEHL
dialogues.text: What’s the matter? We can charge a university professor with indecency.

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE NOCK
dialogues.text: No. No. This is bloody rubbish. Turing is up to something important, not getting his jollies in some pub.  68.

dialogues.speaker: SUPERINTENDANT SMITH
dialogues.text: He committed a crime. He broke the law. And with a bloke, Christ, it’s bloody disgusting.

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE NOCK
dialogues.text: I don’t care if it’s disgusting. This is not the investigation I was conducting.

dialogues.speaker: SUPERINTENDANT SMITH
dialogues.text: Clearly. (to Staehl) Bring him in.

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE NOCK
dialogues.text: Wait. Let me interrogate him.

dialogues.speaker: SUPERINTENDANT SMITH
dialogues.text: You’re asking me for a favour right now?

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE NOCK
dialogues.text: Please. I know him. I know he’s hiding something and I know I can get him to talk... Give me half an hour alone and then I swear to you I will spend the next month running errands on as many rubbish cases as you like.

dialogues.speaker: SUPERINTENDANT SMITH
dialogues.text: ... Fine. Now will someone get a warrant for the arrest of Alan Turing?

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: JOAN’S FLAT - DAY - 1941 Joan comes home to her flat. She looks sad as she puts he key in the lock and opens the door. She enters to find:

dialogues.speaker: LIVING ROOM.
dialogues.text: She sighs.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN CLARKE
dialogues.text: Alan?  69. At the sound of her voice, Alan comes out of the wash roo wiping the shaving cream from his face. He’s moving and talking a mile a minute. Joan sits

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: Christopher is simply not moving fast enough.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN CLARKE
dialogues.text: We should talk. down, sadly.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: (totally oblivious) Even with the diagonal board he’s not eliminating settings as quickly as —

dialogues.speaker: JOAN CLARKE
dialogues.text: Alan, I’m leaving.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: You just walked in.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN CLARKE
dialogues.text: No. Bletchley.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: JOAN CLARKE
dialogues.text: It’s my parents... I am twenty-five and I am unmarried and I am living alone... And they want me home.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: That’s ridiculous.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN CLARKE
dialogues.text: That's my parents.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: You cannot leave. I won’t let you.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN CLARKE
dialogues.text: “T'll miss you.” That’s what a normal person might say in this situation.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: I don’t care what’s normal.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN CLARKE
dialogues.text: “I'll write.” That'd work too.  70.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: No. This is unacceptable. You are not leaving and that is that.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN CLARKE
dialogues.text: What am I supposed to do, Alan? I will not give up my parents. The world is burning to ash and they are my family and they want me home.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: You have the opportunity here to make some actual use of your life —

dialogues.speaker: JOAN CLARKE
dialogues.text: — And end up like you? No thanks. I’m sorry you're lonely. I’m sorry no one likes you. But Enigma will not save you. Can you decypher that, you fragile narcissist? Or do you need me to fetch your precious Christopher for help? Silence. Alan looks like she just slapped him across the face. Whi she basically did.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN CLARKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m sorry.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: I want you to stay because I like you.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN CLARKE
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: I like talking to you.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN CLARKE
dialogues.text: I like talking to you, too, Alan.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: What if you weren’t living alone... If you had a husband?

dialogues.speaker: JOAN CLARKE
dialogues.text: You have one in mind?

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: I do.  71.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN CLARKE
dialogues.text: Hugh is terribly attractive, I'll give you that, but he’s really not the marrying type.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: I wasn’t referring to Hugh.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN CLARKE
dialogues.text: Peter? He’s so quiet... Alan stares at Joan. She stares back.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN CLARKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (getting it) Oh dear Lord.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: This makes sense.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN CLARKE
dialogues.text: Did you just propose to me?

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: It’s the logical thing to do.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN CLARKE
dialogues.text: This is ridiculous.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: This is your parents.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN CLARKE
dialogues.text: (trying to process) I cannot believe this is happening. Alan fishes a piece of ELECTRICAL WIRE from his pocket...

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: Joan Ca... Wait, is your middle mame Caroline or Catherine?

dialogues.speaker: JOAN CLARKE
dialogues.text: Elizabeth.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: Joan Elizabeth Clarke, will you marry me? wee And then FASHIONS IT INTO A RING. ON JOAN'S FACE: What’s she going to do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An impromptu ENGAGEMENT PARTY in the Beer Hut that night: — A BANNER made from PUNCH CARDS reads: “CONGRATULATIONS! — Music plays as DANCERS TWIRL in the center of the Hut. — Joan LAUGHS with her WREN FRIENDS in one corner, while another Alan drinks beer with his team. ON JOAN AND THE GIRLS: She shows off her makeshift wire engagement ring:

dialogues.speaker: JOAN'S FRIEND
dialogues.text: (trying her best) «+. It’s... beautiful? Joan LAUGHS. She understands.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN CLARKE
dialogues.text: I know it’s not an ordinary ring.. She looks over at Alan warmly.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN CLARKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ++. But who ever loved ordinary? ON ALAN AND THE BOYS: They’re are all a bit drunk, TELLIN

dialogues.speaker: HUGH ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: ».. So she’s got it in her hands, right, and she looks up at me and says, “I’m to put it in my mouth?” And I say, “yes, you know. The French way.” So she pops it in, closes her lips around the thing... And then she starts humming the bloody Marseillaise! The men BURST INTO LAUGHTER. Except for Alan, who looks a bit confused.

dialogues.speaker: PETER HILTON
dialogues.text: (to Alan) What about you and Joan? Does she do it the French way? Alan looks away, uncomfortable.

dialogues.speaker: HUGH ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: Soon enough, you lucky bastard.  Just then, 73. Joan comes over and throws an affectionate arm around Alan. Hugh takes

dialogues.speaker: JOAN CLARKE
dialogues.text: Care for a dance?

dialogues.speaker: HUGH ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: No no, your fiancé can dance with you anytime he likes. Now it’s my turn. Joan's hand, and leads her across the room. They begin to DANCE, while Peter follows, dancing with one of Joan’s friends. Alan and John are left alone at the table. Alan looks Alan looks worried.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN CAIRNCROSS
dialogues.text: What’s the matter?

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: ++». What if I don’t fancy... being with Joan in that way?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN CAIRNCROSS
dialogues.text: Because you’re a homosexual? at him, surprised.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN CAIRNCROSS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I suspected. You’re not quite as much of an enigma as you think you are. Or as much as Enigma is.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: Should I tell Joan? I’ve had affairs. With other men.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN CAIRNCROSS
dialogues.text: You know, in my admittedly limited experience, women tend to be a bit touchy about accidentally marrying homosexuals. I think perhaps not spreading this information around might be in your best interest.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: Having children, a family... I want that with her. I do. I just don’t know if I can... Pretend...  74.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN CAIRNCROSS
dialogues.text: You can’t tell anyone, Alan. It’s illegal. And Denniston is looking for any excuse he can get to put you away.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: ++. I know.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN CAIRNCROSS
dialogues.text: This has to stay a secret, or trust me, they’ll kill you for it. ON ALAN: He knows John is right. As Alan thinks, Joan comes back over and offers him her h

dialogues.speaker: JOAN CLARKE
dialogues.text: Come on, now it’s your turn. She leads him to the dance floor. As they START TO DANCE, chastely, sweetly, WE

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. SHERBORNE SCHOOL FOR BOYS - ALAN’S ROOM - DAY - 1927 CLOSE ON A LETTER: “I LOVE YOU” is written on the paper. REVEAL: Young Alan sits in his dormitory room, ENCRYPTING love letter to Christopher. Slowly, letter by letter, Alan transforms “I LOVE YOU” in code... Hearing a commotion, Alan LOOKS OUT THE WINDOW: BOYS are being unloaded from a BUS at the gates, dropped to begin the new spring term. Alan sees them all, excited: Christopher is coming back! He STUFFS HIS ENCRYPTED LETTER IN AN ENVELOPE and RUNS OF

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alan waits eagerly by the main gate as BOYS STREAM PAST — — Joking, horsing around — — Alan waits patiently, looking for Christopher’s face am the rowdy schoolboys —  75. — Until: They’re all gone. Christopher never shows. Alan looks at his undelivered note, then at the empty yar before him. Where is Christopher? Confused, Young Alan finally gives up... ++. When he runs into the PACK OF BOYS who beat him up earlier.

dialogues.speaker: BOY
dialogues.text: Well look. Mr. Turing is all alone. Young Alan stands frozen as they come at him, and we

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alan Turing sits alone in the interrogation room with his eyes closed. Detective Nock enters.

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE NOCK
dialogues.text: Cup of tea?

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: (eyes closed) Thanks, no.

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE NOCK
dialogues.text: ++. Mr. Turing, may I tell you a secret?

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: I’m quite good with those.

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE NOCK
dialogues.text: I’m here to help you. Suddenly, Alan opens his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: (re: being in jail) Clearly.

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE NOCK
dialogues.text: (changing tacks) Can machines think?  76.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: You've read my published work.

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE NOCK
dialogues.text: What makes you say that?

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: Because I’m sitting in a police station, accused of entreating a young man to touch my penis, and you’re asking me whether machines can think.

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE NOCK
dialogues.text: Can they? Could machines ever think as human beings do?

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: Most people say no.

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE NOCK
dialogues.text: You're not most people.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: The problem is that you’re asking a stupid question.

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE NOCK
dialogues.text: I am?

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: Of course machines can’t think “as human beings do.” A machine is different from a human being; hence, it would think differently. The interesting question is, just because something thinks differently from you, does that mean it’s not thinking? We allow that humans have such divergences from one another. You like strawberries. I hate ice-skating. You cry at sad films. I’m allergic to pollen. What does it mean to have different tastes — different preferences — other than to say that our brains work differently? That we think differently from one another? And if we can say that about each another, why can’t we say the same for brains made of copper and steel?

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE NOCK
dialogues.text: That’s... This big paper you wrote... What’s it called?  77.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: “The Imitation Game.”

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE NOCK
dialogues.text: Right. That’s what it’s about?

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: (thinking) ++. Would you like to play?

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE NOCK
dialogues.text: Play?

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: The game. It’s a test, of sorts. For determining whether something is a machine, or a human being.

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE NOCK
dialogues.text: How do we play?

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: There's a judge, and a subject. The judge asks questions, and based on the subject’s answers, he determines: Who is he speaking with? What is he speaking with? All you have to do is ask me a question.

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE NOCK
dialogues.text: ++. What did you do during the war?

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: I worked in a radio factory.

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE NOCK
dialogues.text: What did you really do during the war? Alan smiles — Detective Nock is smarter than he looks.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: ++. Are you paying attention?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alan and his team — Hugh, John, Peter — anxiously stand before Alan’s huge machine as it CLACK CLACK CLACKS, ferociously loud. The gears are spinning, current is flowing through the wi and the team stares at it, taking turns compulsively chec their watches.  78. ON ALAN: This is going to work. This has to work. Suddenly... DING. The chime announces the stroke of midnight.

dialogues.speaker: HUGH ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: Damn it! Everyone is pissed, frustrated. Alan looks as if he’s about to rip his own hair out: Why won’t this damned thing work? As the machine CLACKS on, oblivious, they all walk outsid

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The team walks across Bletchley together, moving as one through the most highly secret war zone in the world. MORE SECURITY has been added throughout the park, includi along the path from Hut 11 — ARMED GUARDS check IDs, whic the team hands over absentmindedly.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN CAIRNCROSS
dialogues.text: We’re soon out of time. Our month...

dialogues.speaker: PETER HILTON
dialogues.text: So that’s it then. We lost.

dialogues.speaker: HUGH ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: It does not matter how much we improve on it, that machine will never be able to check 159 million million million possibilities in time.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: It’s searching... It’s just... It doesn’t know what it’s searching for... If only we knew what the messages were going to say...

dialogues.speaker: JOHN CAIRNCROSS
dialogues.text: If we knew what the messages were going to say, we wouldn’t have to decrypt them at all. ON ALAN: Maybe it was always impossible after all.  79.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It’s crowded in the beer hut, even this late at night. On one side of the room, Alan, Hugh, John, and Peter are drinking. Commiserating about their fate. On the other side, Joan is drinking with her friend HELEN fellow WREN.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: Who’s Alan’s friend?

dialogues.speaker: JOAN CLARKE
dialogues.text: Hugh? Bit of a cad, actually.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: So my type then?

dialogues.speaker: JOAN CLARKE
dialogues.text: Here, I’1ll introduce you.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: No! Lord, engaged for a fortnight and you’ve already forgotten how to do this? He’ll come over.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN CLARKE
dialogues.text: Are you sure?

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: Yes. I smiled at him fifteen minutes ago and haven’t looked at him since.

dialogues.speaker: ON HUGH, ALAN, JOHN, AND PETER
dialogues.text: Hugh is looking at the girls.

dialogues.speaker: HUGH ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: (re: Helen) Who's that, then?

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: Helen? Works with Joan in the WREN’s hut.

dialogues.speaker: PETER HILTON
dialogues.text: You do have a point about the little hats.

dialogues.speaker: HUGH ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: She wants me to come over.  80.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: How can you possibly know that?

dialogues.speaker: HUGH ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: She smiled at me awhile back and hasn’t looked again since.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: (cre: Hugh’s glances) And... Got him.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN CLARKE
dialogues.text: Is it odd that when I was single this game felt tedious, but now it seems just dreadfully fun?

dialogues.speaker: HUGH ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: (ve: Helen’s glances) And... Brilliant. She’s in. Alan, introduce me.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: Why me?

dialogues.speaker: HUGH ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: Because there is nothing like a friend’s engagement to make a woman want to do something she will later regret with the fiancé’s better- looking chum. Hugh drags Alan across the pub to Helen and Joan.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN CAIRNCROSS
dialogues.text: Half crown says Alan bollockses this up entirely.

dialogues.speaker: PETER HILTON
dialogues.text: No bet.

dialogues.speaker: HUGH ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: (to the ladies) Alan Turing has a theory.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN CLARKE
dialogues.text: He has many.  81.

dialogues.speaker: HUGH ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: He believes that the regulations against men and women working side- by-side are sound, because such proximity will necessarily lead to romance.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: No I don’t — Hugh KICKS Alan, who shuts up. Hugh looks Joan picks

dialogues.speaker: HUGH ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: — However, I disagree.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: You do?

dialogues.speaker: HUGH ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: I think that if I were working beside a woman all day long, I could manage to appreciate her abilities and intellect without needing to take her to bed. (to Helen) Pardon, have we met?

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: I don’t recall. But let’s assume we haven't. at Alan for an introduction: Alan is silent. up the slack:

dialogues.speaker: JOAN CLARKE
dialogues.text: Helen Stewart, Hugh Alexander.

dialogues.speaker: HUGH ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: So who do you agree with? Alan or myself?

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: Well, Alan, of course.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: I’m flattered, but this is not actually — Now Joan KICKS Alan, who is still very confused.

dialogues.speaker: HUGH ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: — Rubbish.  82.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: I work beside a man every day, and I can’t help but have developed a bit of a crush on him.

dialogues.speaker: HUGH ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: Well who is this man, so I can kick his arse?

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: Oh, it’s been chaste, you've no need to worry. We’ve never even met. He’s a German.

dialogues.speaker: HUGH ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: Now I really want to kill him.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: How do you mean you work alongside a German?

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: Each of us intercepts messages from a specific German radio tower. So we've a counterpart on the other side, who’s tip-tapping out the messages. Everybody types a touch differently; you get to know the rhythm of your counterpart. It’s strangely intimate. I feel as if we know each other. Pity he has a girlfriend... But that’s why I disagree with you. I’m in love with a co-worker, of sorts, even if we've never met.

dialogues.speaker: HUGH ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: I’ll require another pint to tell you why you’re wrong.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: Let's. Helen and Hugh walk away to the bar...

dialogues.speaker: JOAN CLARKE
dialogues.text: (to Alan) That’s what flirting looks like. In case you were curious. But Alan is lost in thought... Something is wrong...

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: (screaming)

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: Everyone in the room turns and stares at him. Joan winces. Helen and Hugh come back over.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: Yes, Alan?

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: Why do you think your German counterpart has a girlfriend?

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: Oh, it’s a stupid joke, don’t worry about it.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: Tell me.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: Each one of his messages begins with the same five letters. C-I-L-L- Y. So I suspect Cilly must be the name of his amore.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: That’s impossible. The Germans are instructed to choose five letters at random to start every message.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: Well, this bloke doesn’t.

dialogues.speaker: HUGH ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: Love’l1l make a man do strange things, I suppose. Anyhow —

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: — In this case, love just lost the Germans the whole bloody war. Alan BOLTS out of the bar — — SPILLING BEER ALL OVER HELEN — — Who CRIES OUT, and ANGRILY RUNS OFF — — Leaving Hugh and Joan standing there, confused. They share a look: What’s gotten into Alan? Joan quickly RUNS OFF after Alan — — Hugh follows suit — 83.  84. — And John and Peter, seeing this across the room, take o after Hugh —

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone chases Alan across Bletchley Park — — GUARDS YELL at Alan as he bypasses security checkpoints — Guards are screaming at them, drawing guns as he and Jo barrel into Hut 8 — — Hugh and John show their IDs to the Guards, yelling bac them — — Hugh and John finally get rid of the guards and enter:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: — Joan runs into the Hut to find that Alan has grabbed a OF PREVIOUSLY DECRYPTED MESSAGES — — Alan POURS those messages out all over the floor —

dialogues.speaker: JOAN CLARKE
dialogues.text: Alan? — Hugh, John, and Peter enter as Alan spreads the message out on the floor. (Just like he did in Joan’s flat!)

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: What if Christopher doesn’t have to search through all the settings? What if he only had to search the ones that produce the words we already know will be in the message?

dialogues.speaker: HUGH ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: Repeated words! Predictable words... — They all search the messages with Alan — — Joan holds up a DECRYPT: It’s the same one she read earlier.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN CLARKE
dialogues.text: Like this? (reading aloud) “0600 hours. Weather today is clear. Rain in the evening. Heil Hitler.”  85.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: Yes! That’s it! (looking at message) They send a weather report at 6AM. Every day. That means there are three words we already know will be in the 6am message. “Weather,” obviously, and —

dialogues.speaker: HUGH ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: “Heil bloody Hitler.”

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: Heil bloody Hitler. Joan searches through a PILE, finding:

dialogues.speaker: JOAN CLARKE
dialogues.text: Here’s the 6 o’clock message from this morning. Joan holds the message as they all run out to:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alan runs from Hut 8 to Hut 11, the team chasing behind h

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alan, Joan, John, Peter and Hugh burst in —

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: Hugh — the right hand letter-rings. Set them to —

dialogues.speaker: HUGH ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: — I know, I know. “Veter.” “Hitler.” — Hugh turns the rings while —

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: — Peter, John — Run voltage from those rings through the back scramblers — — John and Peter go around back —

dialogues.speaker: JOHN CAIRNCROSS
dialogues.text: — So we'll use the loops?  86.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: — Yes. Joan, what’s the last 6am message? Joan reads aloud to Alan as he enters it in:

dialogues.speaker: JOAN CLARKE
dialogues.text: L-H-W-A-U-Q-X-kK... They all stand back as Alan TURNS ON the machine. They watch the CLACK CLACK CLACK of Christopher as he processes the message... — They’re nervous, fretting, anxiously awaiting his calculations... Finally, Christopher STOPS. Silence, as a SERIES OF ROTORS on the side of Christopher snap into place, displaying a SET OF LETTERS.

dialogues.speaker: PETER HILTON
dialogues.text: What happened? Did it work? Alan SCRIBBLES down the letters ("EXBAO...”) and they all back to —

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where Alan takes a DUMMY ENIGMA MACHINE, turns the machin rotors to the setting he wrote down ("EXBAO...”) —

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: Give me a fresh message. The last one we intercepted. Peter hands Alan one from a nearby folder — — Alan starts typing one of today’s gibberish encrypted messages into Enigma — — As John TAKES DOWN the decoded German letters — — Hugh looks at what John is writing and TRANSLATES the German into English —

dialogues.speaker: HUGH ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: “KMS Jaguar... Is auf punkt —- is directed - 53 degrees, 24 minutes north... And auf punkt 1 degree west...”  87. HUGH ALEXANDER (CONT’D) ALAN TURING “,.. Heil Hitler.” “,.. Heil Hitler.” Alan and Hugh look at each other: Oh my god.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: Turns out that’s the only German you need to know to break Enigma. The team EXPLODES WITH JOY. LAUGHING, HOOTING, SCREAMING, JUMPING, HUGGING. This is the happiest moment of their lives. John even starts to TEAR UP, and TRIES TO HUG ALAN — — Who just STANDS THERE, limp.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN CAIRNCROSS
dialogues.text: (re: Alan) Not a hugger. Probably could have guessed that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dawn rises over Bletchley Park.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The team has been there working all through the night. There’s a flurry of activity: Decoding messages, translat the decrypts, reading the information contained within. Hugh steps back for a moment to look at the product of th work: A BIG MAP ON THE WALL. ON THE MAP: It’s the Atlantic Ocean. Blue pins represent Allied ships, red ones represent the Axis ships.

dialogues.speaker: HUGH ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: You did it. (turns to Alan) Bloody hell, you did it. You just defeated Nazism with a crossword puzzle. What does it feel like to do the impossible? ON ALAN’S FACE: He’s not sure. Something is bothering him but he can’t figure out what. John steps back from his work to join Hugh.  88.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN CAIRNCROSS
dialogues.text: There are five people in the world who know the position of every ship in the Atlantic. They are all in this room. Now Joan joins Hugh and John in seeing the full map for t first time. Hugh picks Hugh DIALS

dialogues.speaker: JOAN CLARKE
dialogues.text: Oh my good God.

dialogues.speaker: HUGH ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: I don’t think even He has the power that we do right now.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN CLARKE
dialogues.text: (getting closer to map) There’s going to be an attack on a British passenger convoy. There.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN CAIRNCROSS
dialogues.text: You’re right. Those U-Boats are only twenty or thirty minutes away.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN CLARKE
dialogues.text: Civilians. Hundreds of them. We can save their lives.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN CAIRNCROSS
dialogues.text: And knock out a whole German fleet in the process.

dialogues.speaker: HUGH ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: I’ll call Denniston. Have him radio his Admirals immediately. up the phone —

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: (figuring something out) No.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN CLARKE
dialogues.text: Is there enough time to save them?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN CAIRNCROSS
dialogues.text: Should be. If we can get a message to the passenger convoy, she can turn —  89.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: (louder) No. No.

dialogues.speaker: HUGH ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: (into phone) — Commander Denniston’s office —

dialogues.speaker: HUGH ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: (into phone) — This is urgent, top priority —

dialogues.speaker: NO
dialogues.text: Alan LEAPS ACROSS THE ROOM and GRABS THE PHONE FROM HUGH.

dialogues.speaker: HUGH ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: What the bloody hell? Hugh tries to grab the phone back — — But Alan pulls away sharply. Everyone STOPS. Turns. Looks at Alan. HUGH ALEXANDER (CONT’D) Are you mad?

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: No. No. You can’t call Denniston. You can’t tell him about the attack.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN CLARKE
dialogues.text: Alan, are you all right? What’s going on?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN CAIRNCROSS
dialogues.text: We can have air support over the passenger convoy in ten minutes.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: No. Let the U-Boats sink the convoy.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN CAIRNCROSS
dialogues.text: Look, this has been a big day, maybe you’re going through a bit of shock —

dialogues.speaker: HUGH ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: — There’s no time for this.  90. Hugh tries to GRAB THE PHONE from Alan — = but Alan PULLS it away and SMASHES THE PHONE AGAINST TH GROUND.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN CLARKE
dialogues.text: Alan! Hugh can’t take it anymore — — He TAKES A SWING AT ALAN — — Who CRUMPLES AT THE BLOW ON HIS JAW — — Hugh stares down at Alan, who’s bleeding on the floor — — Hugh WINDS UP FOR ANOTHER PUNCH — — When Joan CATCHES HIS ARM mid-swing — — Surprised, Hugh instinctively SWINGS AT HER — — Smacking Joan hard across the face. — He’s stunned by what he’s done as she responds by PUSHI HIM INTO A TABLE — — And Hugh falls to the floor, next to Alan. Joan stands above them.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN CLARKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to Hugh) If you hurt him, you will just barely live to regret it. Silence. Just the sounds of panting.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN CAIRNCROSS
dialogues.text: Everyone stop. Please. Calm down.

dialogues.speaker: PETER HILTON
dialogues.text: The attack is in minutes. We don’t have time to calm down.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: Do you know why people like violence, Hugh? Because it feels good. (wipes blood from his nose) It would feel good to blow those U- Boats out of the Atlantic. But sometimes we can’t do what feels good. We have to do what’s logical.  91.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN CAIRNCROSS
dialogues.text: What’s logical?

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: The hardest time to lie is when the other person is expecting to be lied to.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN CLARKE
dialogues.text: (getting it) Oh my God.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN CAIRNCROSS
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: If they’re waiting for a lie, you can’t just give them one.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN CLARKE
dialogues.text: Oh my God. Damn it. Alan’s right.

dialogues.speaker: PETER HILTON
dialogues.text: What?!?

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: What will the Germans think if we destroy those U-Boats?

dialogues.speaker: PETER HILTON
dialogues.text: Nothing. They’ll be dead.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN CAIRNCROSS
dialogues.text: (getting it) No. No. You can’t be right.

dialogues.speaker: PETER HILTON
dialogues.text: Am I the only one who’s still not getting this?

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: Suddenly our convoy veers off course and a fleet of RAF bombers magically descends on the location of a pack of U-Boats? What will the Germans think?

dialogues.speaker: PETER HILTON
dialogues.text: Hugh?

dialogues.speaker: HUGH ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: The Germans will know we broke Enigma.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN CLARKE
dialogues.text: They'll put a halt on radio communication by noon. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: JOAN CLARKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And they’ll have the design of Enigma changed by the weekend.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: Two years of work. Everything we’ve done here. It’1ll all be for nothing.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN CAIRNCROSS
dialogues.text: There are 500 people in that convoy. Civilians. Women. Children. We're about to let them die.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: Our job wasn’t to save one passenger convoy. It was to win the war.

dialogues.speaker: HUGH ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: Our job was to break Enigma.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: Done. Now for the hard part: keeping it a secret. Forever. Peter looks at the map...

dialogues.speaker: PETER HILTON
dialogues.text: It’s the Carlisle. They all look at him.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN CLARKE
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: PETER HILTON
dialogues.text: The convoy you’re about to... It’s... The HMS Carlisle is one of the ships.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: So?

dialogues.speaker: PETER HILTON
dialogues.text: We can’t act on every piece of intelligence? Fine. We won’t. Just this one. The Germans won’t find us out if we stop one attack.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN CLARKE
dialogues.text: What’s gotten into you, Peter?

dialogues.speaker: PETER HILTON
dialogues.text: ++. My brother. Phillip. He’s on the Carlisle. Gunnery ensign.  93. Silence. Fuck.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: I’m sorry.

dialogues.speaker: PETER HILTON
dialogues.text: Who the hell do you think you are? This is my brother. My big brother. He was the only one — Look, he was there after my mum — He’s my big brother, alright, and you have a few minutes to call off his murder.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: It’s not my fault. Peter DIVES for Alan — — But John stops him.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN CAIRNCROSS
dialogues.text: Alan is right. We can’t.

dialogues.speaker: PETER HILTON
dialogues.text: AND WHY THE BLOODY HELL NOT? I am begging you. Alan. Joan. Hugh. John. Please. I am begging you. Just this once. Just one time. The Germans won’t get suspicious just because we stopped one attack. It’s one time. No one will know. I’m asking you. As your friend. If I mean anything to you. Please. Silence. This is the hardest thing anyone in this room ha ever had to do.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: I’m so sorry.

dialogues.speaker: PETER HILTON
dialogues.text: You’re not God, Alan. You don’t get to decide who lives and who dies.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: Yes, we do.

dialogues.speaker: PETER HILTON
dialogues.text: Why? Why?

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: Because no one else can.  94.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alan and Joan ride the train from Bletchley into London. They know what they have to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alan and Joan exit the train and walk down the platform.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a quiet TEA SHOP, Alan, Joan, and Stewart Menzies sip their Twinings. Outside the GLASS WINDOWS, NURSES help WOUNDED SOLDIERS out of an AMBULANCE and into a local HOSPITAL.

dialogues.speaker: STEWART MENZIES
dialogues.text: Why are you telling me this?

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: We need your help to keep this from the Admiralty. Army. RAF. No one can know we broke Enigma, not even Denniston.

dialogues.speaker: STEWART MENZIES
dialogues.text: Who is in the process of having you fired.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN CLARKE
dialogues.text: You'll take care of that.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: While we develop a system for determining how much intelligence to act on. Which attacks to stop, which to let through. Statistical analysis. The minimum number of actions it’ll take to win the war, but the maximum number we're able to take before the Germans get suspicious.

dialogues.speaker: STEWART MENZIES
dialogues.text: You’re going to trust this all to statistics? To maths?

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: Correct.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN CLARKE
dialogues.text: And then MI-6 can come up with the lies we'll tell everyone else.  95.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: We'll require a believable alternate source for each piece of information we use.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN CLARKE
dialogues.text: A false story that exlains how we got that information, that has nothing to do with Enigma. And then you'll need to leak those stories to the Germans.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: And the rest of our military.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN CLARKE
dialogues.text: Can you do that?

dialogues.speaker: STEWART MENZIES
dialogues.text: Maintain a conspiracy of lies through the highest levels of our government? Yes, that sounds right up my alley. ON ALAN AND JOAN: Okay. Let’s do it.

dialogues.speaker: STEWART MENZIES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (smiling) Alan, I so rarely have cause to say this. But you are exactly the man I always hoped you would be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alan and Joan ride the train back to Bletchley. She reaches out and puts her hand in his. They’re in this deep now... But at least they’re in it together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At 6am, dawn is threatening to break across the Park.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: They codenamed it “Ultra.” INT. BLETCHLEY PARK - WREN’S HUT - SEQUENCE But in the WREN’S HUT, the women eagerly await the coming the day’s first messages —  96. — And a sudden BEEP BEEP BEEP announces that they have. T WRENS quickly take down the first messages —

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: And it quickly became the largest store of military intelligence in the history of the world. A WREN removes the first few dozen from a pile — — And hands it over to another WREN —

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: — In Hut 11, the WREN gives the day’s first messages to H who enters them into Christopher —

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: It was like having a tap on Himmler’s intercom. — Christopher HUMS — — And Hugh, after a few minutes, reads the day’s Enigma settings on the machine’s read-out: “FSOQR”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack turns his Enigma machine to the day’s setting — “FSO — and one by one types in the newly intercepted messages, recording the now decrypted results in a BOOKLET. On the cover, the booklet is marked: “ULTRA.”

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: Secrecy became the primary concern. And for some reason they trusted me. Alan organizes stacks of similar ULTRA booklets when he h trouble finding one of them — He looks up to see Peter walking nearby.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: Peter, do you have the 9:30 decrypts — But instead of answering, Peter BUMPS HARD against Alan’s shoulder, scattering Alan’s papers to the floor. Jack looks over. Peter keeps on walking. No one helps Alan as he bends down to clean up his papers Peter LEAVES Hut 8 without speaking a single word.  97. ON ALAN: He’s kneeling down in front of John’s MESSY DESK picking up papers from the floor, when his eyes come leve with something on the desk... It’s a BOOK. Buried underneath CRYPTOGRAPHIC PAPERS. Alan stares at it strangely. Something about its shape an colour look familiar... He UNCOVERS it... If’S A BIBLE. Holy shit. There’s a page dog-eared. Alan opens to the page — it’s Matthew 7:7. “Seek and ye shall find...” ON ALAN: JOHN CAIRNCROSS IS THE SOVIET SPY. Suddenly:

dialogues.speaker: JOHN CAIRNCROSS, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Peter will come around eventually. Alan turns and stands — there’s John, right behind him. ON JOHN: He sees something on Alan’s face. Something is wrong. He looks down at the desk... AND SEES THE UNCOVERE BIBLE. What’s John going to do? Alan is terrified...

dialogues.speaker: JOHN CAIRNCROSS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Jack, could you give Alan and I a moment? Across the room, Jack looks over. Whatever is going on between Alan and John, he wants no part of it. Jack leaves. Alan is now alone with John, the Soviet spy.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN CAIRNCROSS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The Soviets and us, we’re all on the same side. What I’m doing will help Britain.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: I’1l tell Denniston.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN CAIRNCROSS
dialogues.text: No you won’t. Because if you tell him my secret, I’1l tell him yours.  98. ON ALAN: Oh God, John was the one person he trusted.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN CAIRNCROSS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Do you know what they do to homosexuals? You’ll never be able to work again. Never be able to teach. Your precious machine — doubt you’ll ever see him again. ON ALAN: Looks down. He’s beaten. He puts an understanding hand on Alan’s shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN CAIRNCROSS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Until the history books are ready to call you a hero, sometimes you have to play the villain. And with that, John takes his bible and leaves. ON ALAN: What’s he going to do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alan borrows a phone in the central mansion.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: (into phone) I need to speak to Menzies... But frustrated by the response he hears, Alan HANGS UP. INT. BLETCHLEY PARK - JOAN’S FLAT - DAY Alan bursts into Joan’s flat to tell her what he’s found.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: Joan! Joan! Are you there? It’s dark. He FLICKS ON THE LIGHT... REVEAL: The room has been ransacked. Clothes, books, papers scattered everywhere. ALAN TURING (CONT’D) — Joan?!? He quickly moves through the flat: What happened here? ALAN TURING (CONT’D) Joan, are you okay? Where are you?  99. Runs to the back bedroom, where he finds... ... Stewart Menzies. Calmly looking over some papers. ALAN TURING (CONT’D) Where’s Joan?

dialogues.speaker: STEWART MENZIES
dialogues.text: Military prison.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: What have you done?

dialogues.speaker: STEWART MENZIES
dialogues.text: (holding up papers) Decoded Enigma intercepts. A stack of them under her nightstand. ON ALAN: Fuck.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: I gave those to her. A year ago. When she was with the clerks I was—

dialogues.speaker: STEWART MENZIES
dialogues.text: — Yes yes yes, I’m sure. But Denniston has been looking for a Soviet spy, and he’s been looking for one inside Hut 8.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: I know who the Soviet agent is. It’s not Joan. Menzies looks at Alan: Who is it if not her? ALAN TURING (CONT’D) ++. I found the bible... The spy is John Cairncross. Menzies SMILES. As if he’s impressed.

dialogues.speaker: STEWART MENZIES
dialogues.text: +++ God, how I wish you’d been the spy. You’re so much better at this than he is.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: You knew Cairncross was the spy?

dialogues.speaker: STEWART MENZIES
dialogues.text: Well of course Cairncross was the bloody spy. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: STEWART MENZIES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’ve known that since before he got to Bletchley. Why do you think I had him placed here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Flash to the first scene where Alan met his new team afte arriving at Bletchley. Commander Denniston explains how Enigma works, while Menzies stands in the corner, observi Menzies keeps a special eye on Cairncross as Alan and Hug compete over who knows more about cryptography.

dialogues.speaker: STEWART MENZIES, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: You said yourself he was a piss- poor mathematician.

dialogues.speaker: CUT BACK TO
dialogues.text: INT. BLETCHLEY PARK - JOAN’S FLAT - CONTINUED

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: You placed a Soviet agent at Bletchley?

dialogues.speaker: STEWART MENZIES
dialogues.text: It’s quite useful to be able to leak whatever we like to Stalin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A year earlier, John Cairncross exits the Main Gate of Bletchley carrying a SUITCASE —

dialogues.speaker: STEWART MENZIES, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Churchill is too damned paranoid. He won’t share a shred of intelligence with the Soviets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cairncross walks through the village with the suitcase —  101.

dialogues.speaker: STEWART MENZIES, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Even information that will help them against the Germans. So much secrecy...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cairncross comes to a MAILBOX, where under cover of night OPENS HIS CASE — — Removing A FOLDER OF COPIED ENIGMA INTERCEPTS — — Which he then places in the mailbox.

dialogues.speaker: STEWART MENZIES, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Cairncross has no idea we know, of course. Really not the brightest bulb. Cairncross WALKS AWAY into the night. After he leaves, two MI-6 AGENTS come and UNLOCK THE MAIL — Removing his FOLDER — — The Agents take SOME MESSAGES OUT, and put other NEW ON BACK IN — — Before re-sealing the folder and putting it back in the mailbox — — And RE-LOCKING the mailbox lid.

dialogues.speaker: CUT BACK TO
dialogues.text: INT. BLETCHLEY PARK - JOAN’S FLAT - CONTINUED

dialogues.speaker: STEWART MENZIES
dialogues.text: That’s why I’ll need your help now to work out what to leak to John. What to feed the Soviets, as well as the British. ON ALAN: Flustered. Terrified.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: I’m not a spy. I’m just a mathematician.  102.

dialogues.speaker: STEWART MENZIES
dialogues.text: I know a lot of spies, Alan. You’re holding on to more secrets than the best of them. Menzies holds up the stolen decrypts. The threat is palpa

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: You must promise to get Joan out of prison.

dialogues.speaker: STEWART MENZIES
dialogues.text: She’s at the market. She’ll be back in an hour. I lied. (puts the decrypts into his pocket) I'd better hold on to these. If anyone finds out about them, prison will be the least of her worries. ON ALAN: What choice does he have? He looks down.

dialogues.speaker: STEWART MENZIES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh Alan. We’re going to have such a wonderful war together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joan walks towards Hut 8, showing her ID to the new GUARD who are closely monitoring entry to the Huts. In front of Hut 8, Alan watches her. Steeling himself up what he has to do. As she approaches, she sees Alan waiting for her. She smi at him, but he doesn’t return it. Something is wrong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alan and Joan talk behind Hut 8.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: I need you to leave Bletchley.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN CLARKE
dialogues.text: (annoyed) What?

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: Menzies. I don’t trust... ON ALAN: He wants to tell her, but he can’t. It’s too dangerous.  103. ALAN TURING (CONT’D) I don’t think it’s safe here.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN CLARKE
dialogues.text: You think it’s safe somewhere else?

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: You need to leave, and you need to get very far away from me.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN CLARKE
dialogues.text: Alan. What’s happened? ON ALAN: This isn’t working. He’s going to have to try a different approach.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: We can’t be engaged anymore. Your parents will have to take you back and find you a husband elsewhere.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN CLARKE
dialogues.text: What is wrong with you?

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: ».. There’s something I have to tell you. I’m... I’m a homosexual.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN CLARKE
dialogues.text: Alright. ON ALAN: What?

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: Men, Joan. Not women.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN CLARKE
dialogues.text: So what?

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: I just said —

dialogues.speaker: JOAN CLARKE
dialogues.text: — So what? I had my suspicions. I always did. But we’re not like other people. We love each other in our own way, and we can still live the life together that we want. You won't be the perfect husband? I can promise you I harboured no intention of being the perfect wife. I’ll not be fixing your lamb all day awaiting your return from the office, will I? I’11 work. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: JOAN CLARKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You'll work. We’ll have each other’s company. We’ll have each other’s minds. Sounds like a better Marriage than most. Because I care for you. And you care for me. And we understand one another more than anyone else ever has. ON ALAN: He needs to get rid of her, to save her, and she making this impossible.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: I don’t.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN CLARKE
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: Care for you. I never did. I only needed you to break Enigma. And now I’ve done it, so you can leave. She SLAPS HIM.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN CLARKE
dialogues.text: I am not going anywhere. I have spent entirely too much of my life worried about what you think of me, or what my parents think of me, or what the boys in Hut 8 or the girls in Hut 3 think, and you know I am done with it. This work is the most important thing I will ever do in my life. And no one will stop me. Least of all you. Joan turns to walk away, and then, angry, she turns back. She TOSSES HER WIRE ENGAGEMENT RING AT ALAN.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN CLARKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: They were right. John. Hugh. Peter. You really are a monster. Alan watches her walk away, struggling to maintain his fa of icy indifference.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. SHERBORNE SCHOOL FOR BOYS - HEADMASTER’S OFFICE - 19 Young Alan enters the HEADMASTER’S OFFICE.  105.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG ALAN
dialogues.text: You wanted to see me, Sir?

dialogues.speaker: HEADMASTER
dialogues.text: Turing. Sit down.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG ALAN
dialogues.text: Is something the matter?

dialogues.speaker: HEADMASTER
dialogues.text: You and Christopher Morcom are quite close.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG ALAN
dialogues.text: I wouldn’t say that.

dialogues.speaker: HEADMASTER
dialogues.text: Your mathematics teacher says you two are positively inseparable.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG ALAN
dialogues.text: We're the best students in the class.

dialogues.speaker: HEADMASTER
dialogues.text: He caught you passing notes the other day.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG ALAN
dialogues.text: Cryptography. To pass the time. The class is too simple.

dialogues.speaker: HEADMASTER
dialogues.text: You and your friend solve maths problems during maths class because maths class is too dull?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG ALAN
dialogues.text: He’s not my friend.

dialogues.speaker: HEADMASTER
dialogues.text: I’ve been told he’s your only friend.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG ALAN
dialogues.text: Who said that?

dialogues.speaker: HEADMASTER
dialogues.text: Something has come up. About Morcom.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG ALAN
dialogues.text: Why am I here?

dialogues.speaker: HEADMASTER
dialogues.text: Christopher is dead.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG ALAN
dialogues.text: «+. I don’t understand.

dialogues.speaker: HEADMASTER
dialogues.text: His mother sent word this morning. The family was on holiday, you see.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG ALAN
dialogues.text: I don’t understand.

dialogues.speaker: HEADMASTER
dialogues.text: He had bovine tuberculosis, as I’m sure he told you. This mustn’t be a shock, but all the same, I’m sorry.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG ALAN
dialogues.text: You're mistaken.

dialogues.speaker: HEADMASTER
dialogues.text: Did he not tell you? He’s been sick for a long time. Knew this was coming soon, but he had a stiff upper lip about it. Good lad. FACE: Christopher never told him. HEADMASTER (CONT’D) Are you all right, Turing?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG ALAN
dialogues.text: Yes. Of course. As I said, I didn’t know him well.

dialogues.speaker: HEADMASTER
dialogues.text: Ah. Very well then.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG ALAN
dialogues.text: May I leave, Headmaster?

dialogues.speaker: HEADMASTER
dialogues.text: Of course. Oh, but Turing?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG ALAN
dialogues.text: Yes, Sir?

dialogues.speaker: HEADMASTER
dialogues.text: Do pay more attention in maths class, will you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alan, Joan, John, Hugh, and Peter decrypt messages togeth for another two exhausting years.  107.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The war dragged on for another two solitary years. Alan spends two years pressed shoulder-to-shoulder with t woman whose heart he broke. With the man whose dark secre uncovered. With the man whose brother he allowed to die.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Every day we performed our blood- soaked calculus. Every day we decided who lived and who died. And every day we guided the Allied armies to victory without anyone knowing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INTERCUT WITH ARCHIVAL FOOTAGE: The FRONTLINE BATTLES who outcomes, good and bad, are determined by the work of Hut The MEDITERRANEAN FLEET is RAVAGED outside Sicily... 6,00 SHIPS launch for the surprise attack on Normandy...

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Stalingrad? The Ardennes? Normandy? None of those victories would have been possible without the intelligence we produced.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: IN HUT 8: Peter and Hugh each decrypt a message, placing BLUE PINS on the board, and then one RED. They look to Al Two British ships, and they can only save one of them. Alan runs a statistical analysis of their options. We see WORDS: “LIKELIHOOD OF DETECTION,” “CASUALTIES,” “MATERIAL LOSSES” interspersed with mathematical equations. Alan pl his results into a GREEN FOLDER. A MESSENGER comes in and takes the folder to —

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AN MI-6 WAR ROOM: The Messenger delivers the Green Folder Menzies and a TEAM OF MI-6 AGENTS. They look over Alan's analysis and decide what military actions to take. The Ag TELEPHONE Churchill’s office in London.  108.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ARCHIVAL FOOTAGE: We see the impact of Hut 8’s work as a dozen British ships are BLOWN OUT OF THE OCEAN just north Algiers, sacrificed for the greater good in Operation Tor

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BACK IN HUT 8: The team learns of the outcome as they dec more German messages. Peter takes the BLUE PIN down from map, tossing it angrily in the trash. He looks at Alan, w looks away — another ship they could not save.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OUTSIDE BLETCHLEY VILLAGE: Alan RUNS at night on a dirt p along the outskirts of Bletchley. He runs for miles, sweating, panting, until his legs almost give way.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: People talk about the war as this epic battle between civilizations. Good versus evil, liberty versus tyranny. Armies of millions bleeding into the mud, fleets of ships that weighed down the oceans, packs of airplanes that dropped bombs until they blotted out the sun itself. But it wasn’t.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: QUIET MOMENTS IN HUT 8: Hugh lays a folded-up coat under sleeping Peter’s head as a pillow. John makes tea for Joa

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The war was really just a half- dozen crossword enthusiasts in a tiny village in the south of England.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ARCHIVAL FOOTAGE: On V-E Day, Churchill speaks to million from a balcony in Whitehall. Truman dedicates the victory Roosevelt as Times Square erupts into drunken cheers. The whole world kisses. The whole world cries.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Was I God? No. Because God didn’t win the war. I did.  109.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All of Bletchley Park is celebrating the end of the war. Flags are being waved, people are dancing, cheering. But inside the central mansion:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alan and his team are assembled before Stewart Menzies.

dialogues.speaker: HUGH ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: ++. What happens now? Back to the university for us?

dialogues.speaker: STEWART MENZIES
dialogues.text: Yes. You’ve only one thing left to do before your service to your government is concluded.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN CAIRNCROSS
dialogues.text: What’s that?

dialogues.speaker: STEWART MENZIES
dialogues.text: Burn everything.

dialogues.speaker: HUGH ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: STEWART MENZIES
dialogues.text: We told you when you started that this was a top secret program. Did you think we were joking?

dialogues.speaker: HUGH ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: But the war is over.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: This war is over. But there will be more. And we know how to break a code that everyone else thinks is unbreakable.

dialogues.speaker: STEWART MENZIES
dialogues.text: (with a smile at Alan) Alright. Tear it down, light it up, sweep away the ashes. None of you have ever met before. None of you have ever even heard the word Enigma. Have a safe trip home. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: STEWART MENZIES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Behave, and with a bit of luck none of you will ever see me — or one another — again in your lives.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alan Turing finishes telling his story to Detective Nock.

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE NOCK
dialogues.text: That's... Unbelievable.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: That’s the Imitation Game.

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE NOCK
dialogues.text: I don’t know what to do now.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: Now, Detective, you get to judge. That’s how the game works. I answered your questions. You know my story. That’s the point of the game. We are all pretending to be something. Imitating something. Someone. And we are no more, and no less, than what we can convince other people that we are. So tell me: What am I? Am I a person? Am I a machine? Am I a war hero? Am I a criminal?

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE NOCK
dialogues.text: I can’t judge you.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: Well then you’re no help to me at all. ON ALAN: Turning away. He’s done with Nock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A PLAINCLOTHES OFFICER walks through the police station, carrying a NEWSPAPER under his arm. He makes his way to — — Detective Nock’s desk.  111.

dialogues.speaker: PLAINCLOTHES OFFICER
dialogues.text: Congratulations, Sir. The Officer drops the newspaper in front of Nock. The headline reads: “CAMBRIDGE PROFESSOR SENTENCED FOR INDECENCY”, above a photo of Alan. ON NOCK: This should make him happy. But instead he feels only empty and sick. INT. ALAN TURING’S HOUSE - DAY We find Alan in his study. He’s gained weight since last saw him — he’s grown paler as well. Haggard. And the plac a horrible mess. He compares his half-built NEW MACHINE to the plans on hi desk — his work progresses. Slowly. (This is the machine we saw in the opening scene, which appears different but related to the Bletchley machine — a newer model of the same basic concept.) The doorbell RINGS. Alan ignores it, focused on his work. It RINGS again. Irritated, he gets up and shuffles throug his house — — He’s walking with an odd limp, like it’s hard for him t move his legs normally — — And as the bell keeps RINGING insistently he reaches th front door, opening it to find:

dialogues.speaker: JOAN CLARKE
dialogues.text: I had to find out from the bloody newspapers.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. ALAN TURING’S HOUSE - SITTING ROOM - MOMENTS LATER Joan takes a seat while Alan fusses, embarrassed at the s of the place and trying to clean up for her.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN CLARKE
dialogues.text: ++. You never responded to my letters. (silence from Alan) I would have come. I would have testified.  Alan tries «+. Which He is. 112.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: And what would you have said? That I wasn't a homosexual?

dialogues.speaker: JOAN CLARKE
dialogues.text: I would have said something. This is serious. They could send you to jail - to move a glass of water... he DROPS, shattering it.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: Damn it...

dialogues.speaker: JOAN CLARKE
dialogues.text: Your hands... You’re twitching.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: No I’m not.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN CLARKE
dialogues.text: Alan.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: «++. It’s the medication.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN CLARKE
dialogues.text: The medication?

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: I have to go in for weekly oestrogen treatments. At the hospital.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN CLARKE
dialogues.text: What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: The judge gave me a choice. Prison. Or “hormonal therapy.”

dialogues.speaker: JOAN CLARKE
dialogues.text: Oh my god. Oh my god. That’s —

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: — Chemical castration. Yes. To cure my homosexual predilections. Of course I chose that. I wouldn’t be able to work from prison. Joan is HORRIFIED.  113. ALAN TURING (CONT’D) Well how would I even have got parts in jail? It just makes no sense.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN CLARKE
dialogues.text: All right. This is what we’re going to do. I’m going to speak to your doctors. I’m going to speak to your lawyer. We’re going to find a way out of this.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN CLARKE
dialogues.text: You are not thinking clearly. There are a million chemicals flowing through your brain. This treatment—

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: — I’m fine.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN CLARKE
dialogues.text: Please let me help you.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: I don’t need your help.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN CLARKE
dialogues.text: You do not have to do this all alone.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: Alone? I’m not alone. I never have been. He looks lovingly at his machine — at Christopher. ALAN TURING (CONT’D) . Christopher has got so smart. If I stop the treatment, they’1l take him away from me. You can’t let them do that. You can’t. Don’t let them leave me alone. Joan looks at Alan. And at Christopher. His true love. Looking at his machine, Alan starts to have a small PANIC ATTACK — he’s getting more emotional, twitching more, get teary — the hormones are flowing through him.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN CLARKE
dialogues.text: (cre: Alan’s freak out) Here, it’s alright. It’s alright. Sit down.  114. She sits him in a chair, trying to contain his hyperventilating. Alan, embarrassed at this uncontrollable display, tries t play it off, but of course he can’t stop it. With her hand on his shoulder, he notices her WEDDING RIN

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: (trying to seem normal) . It’s a much nicer ring than the one I got you.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN CLARKE
dialogues.text: His name is Jock. We work together in Eastcote. He’s gotten me into coin collecting. Can you believe it? Joan looks around the room for a tea cup, a glass of wate anything that isn’t mouldy she can have him sip from. She sees the newspaper she brought in, grabs it.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN CLARKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Do you want to do a crossword? For old times’ sake. It’ll only take five minutes. Or in your case, six. She tries to get him to smile at her joke. Joan opens the paper to a PUZZLE. Alan looks down at it. His fingers twitch. He stares at the puzzle, confused. He doesn’t know how to do it. Alan moves his hand away from the puzzle.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: Perhaps later. The treatment has wrecked his brain so badly that he can’ crossword puzzles anymore. Joan watches and her heart utterly breaks. ON JOAN: He’s gone forever. And she knows it. Alan sees her sadness. He’s embarrassed, angry, bitter. ALAN TURING (CONT’D) +... At least it worked out for one of us. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ALAN TURING (CONT’D) You got what you wanted, didn’t you? Work. A husband. A normal life. She looks at him quietly for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN CLARKE
dialogues.text: But no one normal could have done this. (gestures to Christopher) This morning I took a train through a city that would not exist if it wasn’t for you. I bought a ticket from a man who would likely be dead if it wasn’t for you. I read up on my work, a whole field of scientific inquiry that only exists because of you. If you wish you could have been ‘normal’, I can promise you, I do not. The world is an infinitely better place precisely because you weren't.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING
dialogues.text: Is that what you think?

dialogues.speaker: JOAN CLARKE
dialogues.text: I think that sometimes it is the very people who no one imagines anything of who do the things that no one can imagine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Young Alan sits under the tree where Christopher first ta him about cryptography. He’s holding the book that Christopher gave him. He starts to cry. He’s alone now, and he will be for a ve long time.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. ALAN TURING’S HOUSE - DAY - 1954 Alan sits at his desk, going over papers. He closes a boo Gets up. Walks past Christopher, giving him a look. He tu off the light, walking away down the dim hallway.  116. EXT. ALAN TURING’S HOUSE - DAY - 1954 A familiar scene: A HALF-DOZEN POLICE OFFICERS swarm the Manchester home of (former) mathematics professor Alan Turing. Detective Nock passes the double-parked police cars and ascends the front steps of Alan’s house. Remembers the first time he was here. INT. ALAN TURING’S HOUSE - CONTINUOUS A CONSTABLE leads Detective Nock upstairs, gesturing into open BEDROOM door. In the doorway, we see a team of COPS tending to somethin the bed. There’s an APPLE on the nightstand.

dialogues.speaker: CONSTABLE
dialogues.text: Suicide, looks like. Half-eaten apple next to the bed. Some sort of white powder all over it.

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE NOCK
dialogues.text: Cyanide. (off the Constable’s look) You'll find a tub of it downstairs. The Constable makes a curious face: How can you know that Nock approaches the bed, and stares into the lifeless fac Alan Turing. ON NOCK: Alan Turing made the world a better place... And Nock killed him for it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alan, Joan, Hugh, John, and Peter stand before the MASSIV BONFIRE that’s been built in the center of the Park. TITLE: Alan Turing committed suicide in 1954. TITLE: His machine was never perfected, though it generated a whole field of research into what became nicknamed “Turing Machines.” Today, we call them “compute Hugh comes over and puts one arm around Alan, another aro Joan. They have a moment: They did it. They won the war. John throws a stack of Enigma messages high into the air  117. — They watch as the papers flutter down into the fire. They laugh, and one by one they all join in: They FROLIC and PLAY as they throw every document, every of scratch paper, every bit of evidence they were there i the fire. TITLE: In 1990, John Cairncross publicly confessed to hav been a Soviet agent. He was never prosecuted. TITLE: In 2013, Turing was granted an official pardon by government. Approximately 49,000 other gay men were convi and punished under the same code between 1885 and 1967. TITLE: The logo of Apple Computer - an apple with a bite taken out of it - has long been rumored to be a silent tribute to Turing. These rumors have never been confirmed

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Well then. ON ALAN AND THE TEAM: Hugging and playing as everything t did is burnt to a crisp.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TURING, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Any questions? BLACK.
